theText: Order! It being 8 p.m.,Wednesday, 20 June 2001 MAIN COMMITTEE 28167 Wednesday, 20 June 2001 ----Education: Schools Funding the federal Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs that he must do all in his power to bludgeon and marginalise public education. In case that statement is regarded as overstated by those opposite, let me prove it to all in this chamber by referring to the only statistic that means anything in the expenditure on education. The percentage of GDP expended on education is falling, and falling dramatically. In 1996-97, it was 2.06 per cent. For 2001-02, it will be around 1.6 per cent. That is a 20 per cent cut. That is the real truth-forget all the other statistics. They account only for inflation and increased enrolments. Historically, elitist conservative forces in Victoria have always tried to marginalise public education. It is part of the psyche in certain quarters in that state. It is still the case, particularly, with the current education minister. This minister is to dogma as propaganda is to indoctrination-George Orwell describes him most accurately. He continues a long line of elitist conservative propaganda agents in Victoria who have always tried to marginalise public education. Those of us who are from states other than New South Wales and Victoria are often bored by the many senseless debates between proponents of those states. However, one comparison between New South Wales and Victoria is particularly edifying when it comes to public and private education. A Victorian educational researcher found that in New South Wales over half the people with entries in Who’s Who were educated in public schools. But when it came to Victoria, over half came not only from private schools but from just five schools: Scotch College, Wesley College, Geelong Grammar, Melbourne Grammar and Geelong College. How much more elitist conservative can you possibly get? The minister obviously wants to keep it that way-just look at where the Victorian contingent of cabinet frontbenchers went to school. This continues an evil tradition of conservative forces in Victoria when it comes to education. In the early 1900s the so-called top private schools in Victoria were successful in limiting the breadth of curriculum offerings in public schools. That is what they went in to bat for, and they actually won it-hard to believe, but true. At various times, even in the 1950s, that divisive debate was continued by elitist conservatives in Victoria to retain for private schools a competitive edge. Of course, the practice of cherry picking the most able from public schools operated then as it does now. Judgment day comes for people who do harm to the future national interest of this nation. Sometimes that day can be very slow in coming, but as certain as night follows day it does come. theText: As somebody who went to Cronulla Public School and28168 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 June 2001 reaction to each proposal and then to rank each one from 1 through to 4 in order of preference. The proposals were to restore the heritage site at Captain Cook’s landing place, to build a museum of reconciliation to celebrate and recognise the meeting of two cultures at Kurnell, to purchase three parcels of privately owned land-zoned 7b-to restore it environmentally for conversion into national park, and to allow the Australand corporation to proceed with its development proposal. In total, 392 completed surveys were received in response from the two areas-144 from Kurnell and 248 from north Cronulla. In regard to the purchase of 7b lands, over both areas the buyback of the degraded lands proved the most popular option, with 351 of the 392 respondents either strongly agreeing or agreeing with it. It was also the proposal that produced the most polarised opinions, with only 14 people indicating that they were indifferent to it. In addition, 73 per cent of respondents rated this as their most preferred option, while only four per cent rated it as their least favourite option. The buyback was more popular amongst North Cronulla residents than Kurnell residents with 75 per cent of North Cronulla respondents rating it a top priority as against 66 per cent in Kurnell. The Australand development proposal was the most unpopular proposition-233 of 392 strongly disagreed with it and 30 disagreed. While 96 either strongly agreed or agreed, only 25 people were indifferent. Sixty-two per cent of respondents across both areas ranked it at No. 4 or least preferred option while it was the favourite option of 14 per cent of respondents. Australand was far more unpopular amongst North Cronulla residents with 70 per cent of them citing it as their least favourite option as opposed to 46 per cent in Kurnell. Improvement of the existing heritage site and inscription points so it better reflects the important place it holds in modern history was the second most popular option. Three hundred and thirteen of 392 respondents agreed or strongly agreed while 30 disagreed and 41 were indifferent. The Museum of Reconciliation concept also received considerable support, 226 agreeing with it while 59 disagreed. By way of conclusion, my survey has conveyed a fairly strong message from the residents of Kurnell and North Cronulla. For the most part they are very keen about the proposal to purchase the degraded lands of the peninsula. Having said this, it is very difficult to move forward a significant way with this proposal without having a concrete land evaluation at this stage. I have heard estimates ranging from as low as $2 million to $3 million up to several hundred million. Clearly this is not a focused enough figure to have a meaningful dialogue. In 1998 and 1999 I spoke in the House, during the adjournment debate, about the frightful circumstances of constituents of mine, a family whose son was murdered in Greece in the middle of 1998. This boy’s name was George Karalis. The matter is, obviously, deeply grieving to the family because of the essential circumstances-it was a particularly horrific murder-but their grief has been added to dramatically by the extreme difficulties they have been experiencing in getting the necessary degree of cooperation from the Greek authorities. Inadequate cooperation has been given not only to them but to Australian judicial bodies, in this case the Coroner’s Court in Victoria. In 1998 the Victorian Coroner issued an order, which I am quite happy to provide to the Attorney General, for the supply of a significant amount of information. Well over a year later, that order was-through the efforts of the Australian post in Athens, I think-largely complied with but not completely, according to my information. On4 September 2000, the Victorian Coroner’s Court issued a quite detailed request-which once again I would be happy to provide to the Attorney-General-for further information. This request relates to obtaining statements by homicide police officers, the harbourmaster of the port of Rafina and forensic examiners, telephone records and the like. From the detail that the Victorian Coroner is seeking, clearly he is satisfied that there are substantive matters for him to look at, yet this considerable time later we do not seem to be getting anywhere through the post in Athens with the appropriate Greek authorities. This is not a matter of an Australian investigating body seeking to put its nose directly into a matter that ought properly to be within the investigative jurisdiction of an overseas country. We have a situation where clearly the way in which Australian courts, in this case the Coroner’s Court in Victoria, seek to carry out their work is not being successful in the way it ought to be. Certainly there is some criticism by the family and by the family solicitor of the way in which DFAT has operated in this matter. The particular issue that I am concerned about is the number of-mostly male-non-custodial parents who find themselves in the Family Court unable to afford proper representation and unable to get legal aid. They raise a series of matters that they believe are important and relevant and find that, as far as the court is concerned, they are totally irrelevant, and this adds to their disillusionment and disenchantment. I realise that it would be extremely difficult for the Commonwealth to get itself into the situation of funding both sides of actions, the progress of which is determined by the parties, and that the parties in these situations are at odds with each other and are not necessarily going to behave reasonably, and the costs could be quite inordinate. speaker: Mr Williams (Tangney
theText: Attorney-General) (10.09 a.m.)-In response to the member28172 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 June 2001 the particular case. We have had some problems in dealing with Greek authorities in relation to criminal matters. It has not been an entirely satisfactory relationship generally. dition treaty or a mutual assistance in criminal matters treaty. Certainly, we have the capacity, through the AFP, to provide assistance to criminal authorities in Greece if it is requested. Here, the circumstances seem to be the other way around-although the offence is committed in Greece, the investigation is in Australia. I would be happy if the member for Maribyrnong were to either write or speak to me, to my office or the department about the circumstances. Basically, dealing with the Greek authorities is the responsibility of DFAT. The AFP has liaison officers in a number of different locations around the world, as the member for Maribyrnong is probably aware. They may be able to provide some assistance if the requisite action is not being taken in Greece. I issue an invitation to the member to raise the matter in a formal way. On the subject of legal aid, raised by the member for Kingston, the circumstances in relation to legal aid that pertained two years ago are really quite different now. It has been the case for some time that issues relating to contact with children between warring spouses have been a running sore in members’ and senators’ electorate offices. Within the last two years, we have taken two major steps that we hope will alleviate some of the problems. One difficulty that many separating spouses face is the cost of proceedings in the Family Court. Specifically to address that problem-where, for example, a father goes to a lawyer and is told that he will have to put down $10,000 in order to commence a case in the Family Court and he will probably have to pay more, when all that he is seeking is regular contact with his childrenwe have established the Federal Magistrates Service, which is specifically designed to provide a cheaper, faster and simpler service. In fact, it is doing that. It has been a very successful institution and is now readily accessed both by lawyers and by unrepresented litigants. The second step that we have taken is to amend the Family Law Act to make provision for better enforcement of orders relating to contact with children. We have instituted a three-step process under which, at the time of separation, the parents are given some counselling. If there is a subsequent breach of the order, they may be ordered to participate in a counselling process. If breaches continue, at the third step there may be penalties invoked. It only came into operation at the end of last year, so it has not had a long time in operation in order to test the effectiveness of it, but we will obviously be monitoring the process to see how it is working. On the proposal specifically mentioned by the member for Kingston to allow the cost of the initial set of orders to be a charge against the assets of the marriage, my initial reaction is that this is unlikely to work. It does not seem to be a matter of money for many of the people who have intractable problems, particularly in relation to residence of, and contact with, the children. I do not specifically recall this proposal being raised two years ago, but we will look at it and, if we see any merit in it, we will see what can be done. The difficulty will be that the parties will have, at some stage, divided the assets, and most of the problems do not seem to arise in relation to contact where one party is legally aided and the other is not at the time of separation, they seem to arise further down the track when the parties have been separated for some time and the property has been divided. It is a complex issue that we will never fully address, but the measures I have mentioned-the creation of the Federal Magistrates Service and the three-step enforcement of contact orders process-will assist. In more recent times I convened a meeting of the Job Network providers to discuss with them the issues that have been brought forward. Out of all this a number of things came forward. One is my very strong suspicion that the network providers are under enormous duress from the government not to talk. There was a great deal of apprehension as to how they would be seen and how they would be interpreted, and this affected what they said. The second thing that is extremely difficult within this portfolio area is the government’s failure to indicate or to have any transparency as to what the providers or network members are being paid to assist job seekers. That creates a very real problem for the job seeker, who goes to an agency thinking that they are there to help them only to discover-in fact, they do not discover most times-that the agency gets paid only if it finds them a position. That is not the expectation because the job seeker does not think that they are going in there only to be supported if they end up in employment. Of course, the agency says, ‘How much is it worth spending on this person? What are the chances of getting them a job?’ So the more difficult to place people are not very good investments. That conundrum, that almost impossible contradiction between the job seeker and the Job Network member, is at the hub of the discontent and the resentment that is now building up. They now get to the next stage, which is a really nice sting in the tail, where the network provider is now required to breach. I had a very simple case not long ago of a man who had an appointment with a Job Network member on a Friday. His son was going to hospital for what was supposed to be minor surgery. On the Monday morning he rang the provider to apologise and to explain his circumstances and was told he had already been breached. Within hours of missing the appointment he had been breached. speaker: Mrs Crosio (Prospect) (10.22 A.m.)
theText: I was going to bow to my colleague. I thought that,Wednesday, 20 June 2001 MAIN COMMITTEE 28175 employment. But at least they had the opportunity of participating in some schemes that were training them to find jobs in the future. What have we seen this do in the budget, in the allocation in the last year, and particularly just recently? My area now has the highest rate of unemployment in any metropolitan local government area in New South Wales-I am talking about metropolitan areas, not the one rural area where it is higher than in mine. This government has allocated two additional Job Network sites to my electorate in the last 12 months. I thought, ‘At least it is a start; it has given two more sites than we had previously to help train, assist and provide opportunities. At least the jobs are there for unemployed people.’ I then went one step further and looked at my neighbouring electorate of Parramatta, the unemployment figures for which are a lot lower than mine. I found that, while the electorate of Prospect had received two new Job Network sites, the electorate of Parramatta-which would probably have half or even less than half the unemployment rate in my area-received five new Job Network sites. I say to the minister, ‘If we are establishing these sites throughout the areas to assist those in need, how can the government blatantly give two sites to an area that has the highest unemployment rate in metropolitan Sydney and five to the neighbouring electorate that probably has a third of the unemployment rate?’ There has to be an explanation for this. I do not believe, and I suppose I am saying this facetiously, that this minister would be so politically bent that he would be looking after what is classified as a marginal seat-Parramatta. The minister knows that they do not have a hope of winning the seat of Prospect. That is one conclusion that I could come to, but I do not wish to do that. I have certainly voiced my feelings, and I am sure the minister has a logical explanation. I am glad he is in the chair and I hope he gives an explanation when he has the right of reply. I do feel that-and, Mr Deputy Speaker, even you would agree with me-if you, as a government, are going to create these Job Network sites, you should look at Australia as a total, divide it down to the states, from the states to the local regional areas, and from there to where the unemployment need is greatest. Surely that is where you would then make provisions to overcome the problems. Unfortunately, we have now seen this on not one but numerous occasions. I am bringing this one up now only because this is the latest scam-two network sites allocated to my electorate of Prospect and five to my next-door neighbour. I might add that the division between the two seats is virtually a road. So you say that on one side of that road they need five extra sites and on the other side two extra sites. I could even go so far as to say that we could join in and share some of the responsibility, but I can assure you that the ones in Parramatta are very much concerned with the seat of Parramatta, as I presume the ones in Prospect are concerned with Prospect. (Extension of time granted) In deference to my colleagues, I will be quick as there is another matter I would like to raise while I am on my feet-that is, the perennial problem this government has with employees’ lost entitlements. The reason why I say it is a perennial problem, as the minister would realise, is that I was the first to introduce a private member’s bill into the House to deal with the total protection of workers entitlements-not the $20,000 cap, which is what we see now with regulation, but 100 per cent protection of workers entitlements. At that stage, as I repeatedly said, I thought we would see some action along the line. I have reintroduced that bill on four separate occasions. The Labor Party have accepted that as part of our overall policy and I am pleased that, when the Labor Party are elected into government at the next election, that is one of the first changes that we will be making to workers’ rights and entitlements. I think it is appalling that, time and time again, commitments have been given and promises have been made, and yet 28176 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 June 2001 firm after firm suffers from insolvency through bad administration and the people who still lose out in the end are the workers who lose their entitlements. In the estimates I went one step further, because the estimates show us the figures: we have forward budgets. After June 2003 there is no guarantee of any employee entitlements or finances for that particular area. I say to the minister-and perhaps he will also answer thiswhat happens after 30 June 2003? After all, there has been no legislation. The intention of the government was given to us by the then minister, Minister Reith, who said in parliament-not in a doorstop interview-on 31 August 1999: The intention of the government in respect of our legislative scheme is to work to put a national scheme in place by 1 January. One only has to add it up: if that was 1 January 2000, it is now 93 weeks since then and we still have not seen any legislation. If we have not got a scheme in place by legislation, we have only got it as an administrative scheme, what do we say to the workers out there who are being continually disadvantaged, at times by the collapse of their employers’ businesses? I believe most members would realise that, when you have a person who has worked for a firm, possibly for 20 or 30 years, and given their lifetime to the job, and then finds, when the firm has gone bankrupt or belly-up-as the common saying is-that they are left without any entitlements whatsoever, it is not good enough to say, ‘But we are a government that has put a scheme in and we are probably going to pay them about 20 cents in the dollar.’ They could end up with no more than $20,000. You will find that most of the payments that have gone out, and there have been very few to date, average about $4,000 to $5,000. There are too many Australians out there who are now being affected by this. It is about time that we as a government, particularly the Howard government after the commitments they have repeatedly made, start putting into place a legislative scheme that guarantees the rights of the workers. That has not come in. The Prime Minister has certainly said on numerous occasions that he is very concerned about the workers, that he is going to act for them and that he is concerned about their families losing the entitlements. I wish he would use the same speed, diligence and determination to act for them that he did when he so miraculously introduced the GST-that he was never ever going to have-into this nation last year. At least on this occasion, with workplace entitlements, we have actually heard a number of ministers, from the Prime Minister down, saying, ‘Yes, we are very supportive. Yes, we are going to act.’ But, of course, what we see, both in the budget papers and in the forward estimates, is that we do not have a legislative scheme in place; we have a regulation where funding is no longer going to be guaranteed after 2003. That is not good enough. More importantly, it is not good enough to give an employee part of his entitlement. If I-and I have used this analogy on many occasions-were caught stealing, I would be sent to jail, and rightfully so. But, if an employee is robbed of his entitlements, no-one-and I mean no-one-in this country wants to stand up and do anything. It is not good enough to say that the regulative scheme that is in place is giving them everything they deserve. It does not; it does not go anywhere near it. It is not good enough not to have legislation in this parliament. I know the excuse is going to be given by the minister that the states have got to come into it as well but I believe he should have a national scheme in place. If you have a national scheme in place, you are strong enough to bite the bullet and then you can surely bring the states in under the umbrella of the Commonwealth. This is what the workers out there are demanding. This is what the workers want and they will settle for no less. The cap, the regulative provision that is in there now, is not good enough and more work has got to be done in this regard. (Time expired) Wednesday, 20 June 2001 MAIN COMMITTEE 28177 tial Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2001-2002 and I just want the committee to bear with me as I include on the record those comments which were pertinent to the particular departments. I begin, in a roundabout way, with small business. I note the comments that consumer savings are not a great problem. The Prime Minister says that increased consumer spending shows that $12 billion worth of tax cuts are still, in his words, ‘being enjoyed’. I can tell you that in my electorate there are not a lot of people who are enjoying spending. My electorate, apart from the Lithgow sector, is, according to statistics, one of the most economically buoyant rural electorates in the country, with its mix of education, a booming mining sector, a strong public sector and a farming sector which-after years of being downtrodden and having negative returns-is showing signs of sustained returns. I did a spot survey of small business people after the so-called positive growth figures that came out recently, and businesses described their results over the past 12 months as ‘patchy at best’. In Lithgow, a major retailer of a clothing store said that their had been no sales to speak of in the key areas of clothing or shoes since July of last year. The retail story from Orange was not much better. The people in business who I spoke with felt that they were treading water. Savings are down and people are forced to use credit for even their most basic groceries. They have little hope of meeting anything other than the minimum monthly payment, so they are accruing debt which, obviously once it hits their credit limit, is going to cause severe problems. Many of them are feeling that now. The tax burden on middle to lower income people is the same or worse-not less. In particular, it is worse for lower income workers. There seems to have been a massive shift in taxing from the relatively well off to the lower income groups. A reduction in tax for lower income people does not have the impact it has for those on a higher level of income. Although there have been tax cuts for all, the impact of the GST has been on those least able to pay. Credit seems to be driving consumption and it is unsustainable. In the first three months of the year, total credit card debt reached a record high of $18 billion after an unprecedented boom in card use during the Christmas-New Year period, particularly during the January sales period, with falling interest rates making debt more attractive and, indeed, a necessary option. Total credit card debt has risen 30 per cent since the March quarter last year, and any boost of growth in spending is false growth indeed. Growth in spending figures per se can be very misleading. Unemployment is again rising, although only gradually, thank heavens, and underemployment is a fact of life. When I look about me in the shopping malls of Orange and Bathurst, I see young people with young families-many of them in the most basic clothing. Both parents rely on part-time or casual work, if they have jobs, or a mix of family support payments, the dole or whatever to get by. I am glad that commentators are now picking up on the underemployment issue, pointing out that one has to work but an hour a week to not appear in the unemployment statistics, and yet, by any judgment, many of these people are as good as unemployed. It amazes me that it has taken so long for that fact to filter through to mainstream commentators. Underemployment has been the hidden poverty of the deregulated labour market and the downturn in regional areas in recent years. There are people who do not feel by any means comfortable with their way of life. (Extension of time granted) If we continue to throw at these people the fact that interest rates are low, unemployment is looking good and we have created hundreds of thousands of jobs, is it any wonder that they become cynical about that process when they know that things are not warm and comfortable for them?
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Andren (Calare) (10.33 A.m.)
theText: I too was squeezed out of the debate on this substan28178 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 June 2001 While a training component for Work for the Dole is long overdue-and I certainly welcome it-the training must be meaningful. Training in information technology has the potential to unlock the lives of the unemployed. I had dinner with a person the other night who is very closely connected with the IT industry-a person of my vintage. She asked me, ‘Do you know anyone who actually makes anything?’ I had to struggle to think of people I know who make things, apart from the people who work at ADI in Lithgow and so on. In terms of close acquaintances, we here in the parliament are moving in areas where information technology is part and parcel of life. We are running into people all the time who live on information creation. That was the point this woman was making. She said that people-even those who in the past we would have regarded as the least skilled manually-can sit in front of a computer and be very computer literate. They know how to handle the technology and they know how to find their way through it. Her argument was that we do not have the sorts of divisions that I have been talking about. We do not have those divisions now, particularly amongst young people, but we need to tap into and encourage the latent ability that is out there amongst so many who are nominally unemployed and who think they have no hope in the older economy. In Lithgow, for instance, their expectations rest with the future of heavy industry. I am trying to suggest-with Lithgow now the first learning city in New South Wales; I launched it a few months ago-that people look over the horizon and beyond heavy industry for their future. People who feel there are no jobs in the mines or in the electricity industry and therefore there is no future have the potential, so close to Sydney, to develop these new technologies and to encourage their kids. I really do think we have an enormous well of talent among people we may have written off when thinking in terms of traditional jobs. If we do not help them to develop the expertise-and I think IT may be the secret here-we will have long-term disconnection, cynicism, suicide and all of those accompanying effects. A few years ago I spoke with Mr Reith about re-badging CDEP-and I have spoken, too, with ATSIC about it-to include the environment. It strikes me that there are any number of training options available in horticulture, irrigation technology, biodiversity and so on that could engage our Koori community in a very positive way. Perhaps they might have some secrets to share with us that we can use to repair our desperately damaged environment. Drawing on their love of the land could probably do a lot for reconciliation. I hope the minister will be able to respond to this. an opportunity in the House to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2001-2002. I want to draw to the minister’s attention one particular problem in my electorate, and I think it may be a much broader national problem, and that is the inflexibility of the Job Network system. In my area I have a high level of indigenous unemployment, which I am sure applies in many parts of Australia. I have people who work within the community-social workers, other providers, people who either are trying to give skills to these people who are unemployed or are actually placing them into jobs-who are not within the Job Network system and are therefore not recompensed for finding people work. They do not begrudge that fact, but there seems to be a system creeping in whereby people in the Job Network who are trying to find jobs for, say, indigenous unemployed people are struggling to do that so they are going outside and getting people in the community to actually find jobs for these people, but then the Job Network people reap the rewards. There seems to be inequity in the system when people can go into the Job Network system and be categorised very early. When they walk in that door they are categorised as ‘Easy to get a job’, ‘Very difficult to get a job’ or ‘Not interested.’ The onus as to whether you have

speaker: Mr Ripoll (Oxley) (10.42 A.m.)
theText: I want to record my disappointment that I did not getWednesday, 20 June 2001 MAIN COMMITTEE 28179 any hope of finding a job remains with the person at the reception desk when you walk into a Job Network agency. It is not just about how employable you are; it is about what hope you have of getting past that first person in the reception area. I think this is a really big problem that the minister needs to look at. Perhaps he can look at ways to make the system more flexible so it can address these issues. Constituents have come to me and said, ‘Look, I am finding it hopeless going to Job Network providers because they are not interested in me. I don’t fit into their neat categories of who might be easiest for them to make a profit from. BecauseI don’t fit into those categories, I don’t get looked after-there is nothing there for me.’ I use the example of indigenous employment in particular but I am sure it is a wider problem. Perhaps the minister could look at this situation where outside agencies and other providers who are not part of the Job Network system are actually doing the hard yards, doing the work of trying to find jobs for people but who are then, at the end, finding that it is the Job Network providers who are actually picking up the money for placing those people into work. Business) (10.45 a.m.)-I would like to begin by thanking the members opposite for their contributions. I think all the members opposite who have spoken in this debate have spoken with goodwill and great sincerity, and all of them have raised important and interesting points, which I will attempt to address as best I can in this response. I will begin with the comments made by the member for Newcastle. Essentially, he made three points. The first point he made was that Job Network members in his electorate were, he said, reluctant to speak out publicly about defects in the system. The second point he made was that people going into the Job Network did not have enough of an idea of the resources that might be available to them through the network. The third point he made was about Job Network allegedly breaching people. I would like to make it very clear that, as far as I am concerned and, I am sure, as far as the government generally is concerned, there is no attempt whatsoever to limit debate nor to restrict people’s contributions to building a better society. Obviously, the more that people who know the system speak about the system, the better. However, I think members opposite need to understand that every time a Job Network member damns the system, he or she runs the risk of damning his or her own operations and, if people are not as ready to criticise the system as members opposite might sometimes like, it is probably because they have, on balance, quite a good opinion of the system and they understand that, while simply running things down might make sense in a political context, it rarely makes sense in a context where people are out there trying to do the right thing as best they can under the ordinary difficulties that people face with the system that they have. As members opposite should know by now, the Job Network is a result of a tender process, and the strict prices at which Job Network members are awarded contracts are commercial-inconfidence. However, generally speaking, if we are talking about intensive assistance, there is an up-front payment to the Job Network member of a little over $1,000, with an outcome payment of a little over $2,000 after 13 weeks and another outcome payment of about $1,000 after 26 weeks. Those amounts vary, depending upon the job seeker’s degree of disadvantage and the particular bids that different Job Network members have put in, but that, broadly speaking, is what the average job seeker referred to a Job Network member for intensive assistance can expect will be available. The idea that, just because someone has been categorised in a certain way, the Job Network member has no more than a particular amount to spend on them is misleading. Job Network members do not just deal with individuals on a one-off basis; they are also dealing with the

speaker: Mr Abbott (Warringah
theText: Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small28180 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 June 2001 collectivity of unemployed people in their area. There are some people who go into intensive assistance and quite quickly get work. The Job Network member gets paid outcome payments for those people which the Job Network member is then expected to invest in other job seekers. So some clients may well have far more spent on them than $4,000 or $8,000 or whatever the actual allocation for that client is. In the end, it is really up to the good faith of Job Network members and, while I am sure that there are some people in the Job Network, as there are in all other areas of life, who think a little bit too much of themselves and a little bit too little of others, by the same token the vast majority of people in the Job Network are extremely sincere and dedicated people. It is not easy to work with job seekers, particularly long-term job seekers, and I do not think there are too many grasping and avaricious capitalists out there in the Job Network. Finally, on the question of breaching, Job Network members are expected to notify Centrelink if their clients are not playing by the rules, but no Job Network member actually breaches anyone. In the end, the enforcement role is the responsibility of Centrelink, the government agency, and that is the way it ought to be. (Extension of time granted) The member for Prospect has been a very long-term, distinguished and senior representative of her part of Western Sydney and I would not for a second doubt the member for Prospect’s commitment to her people and her area. I do think that sometimes she rather exaggerates the difficulties that some people face. The member for Prospect does not quite seem to have appreciated, at least for the purposes of this debate, that the Job Network is not something which is micromanaged by the government. The government does not decide, for instance, that we need two Job Network members in Guildford and five Job Network members in Parramatta and three in Liverpool and four in Chatswood and one in Manly. That is not how the Job Network operates. The Job Network operates like this: different members or would be members bid to provide services in particular sites and, on the basis of the way those bids conform with the tender conditions, we then award contracts. There are certainly more Job Network members in the electorate of Prospect now than there were CES officers in the old days. Given the mobility in a metropolitan area such as Sydney, I understand the member for Prospect’s point, but I think that Job Network members in Parramatta are quite capable of helping job seekers in Prospect, just as Job Network members in Prospect, for that matter, are quite capable of helping job seekers in Parramatta. That is the way it ought to work, and that is my understanding of the way it does normally work. On the question of entitlements, congratulations to the member for Prospect for her long campaign on this subject, which I think actually began under the former government-a government which did not actually do anything for the entitlements of workers. This government has. I accept that there are many people who think that more should be done, but the fact is that this is what is being done. I do think it would help the workers of Prospect and other parts of Australia if the member for Prospect were just as eager to get the state government to do its bit under the existing national scheme as she is to promote the virtues of an alternative national scheme which might possibly be put into place one day, if her friends are ever put into government. I was pleased to hear the contribution of the member for Calare. I was recently in the electorate of Calare as part of the Pollie Pedal. I am sorry that the member for Calare was a bit too busy to join us; nevertheless it is always a pleasure to be in that particularly magnificent part of central western New South Wales. It is always possible to get nods of agreement from any audience by telling them how tough life is. I do not accept the member for Calare’s point that the tax burden on low-paid and badly off people has increased. The statistics certainly do not bear him out. Even conceding that it might be true in some instances, the fact is that that tax is Wednesday, 20 June 2001 MAIN COMMITTEE 28181 being spent on government programs. You cannot on the one hand complain that taxes are going up and on the other hand that government programs have been cut, because the arithmetic simply does not work out. Underemployment is not a recent phenomenon. The ABS has been running statistical surveys on this for a couple of decades now, I think. At the height of the last recession, when the Leader of the Opposition was the minister for employment and unemployment hit close to 11 per cent, the ABS underemployment statistics showed commensurate problems. If you were to add the numbers of underemployed people to the numbers of unemployed people then, in the way people want to do now, unemployment would not have been about 11 per cent-it would have been about 18 per cent. If you want more work, obviously it is frustrating when you do not have it, but sadly this is not a recent phenomenon. Certainly, the quantum of work appears to be greater now than at any time in the recent past. On the subject of CDEP, I take the point that the member for Calare made. I was in Mossman Gorge in Far North Queensland the other week and they are proposing just that kind of thing-to run a CDEP scheme which will focus on guiding services to tourists in the national park which abuts their community. But CDEP, a little like Work for the Dole and the Job Network, is actually a ground up program. (Extension of time granted). It is driven by the grassroots. If indigenous communities wish to reorientate their CDEPs in this direction, there is nothing to stop them from doing so, and if indigenous communities would like to begin CDEPs along these lines, certainly there would be nothing to stop them putting in applications. I would do whatever I could to try to encourage communities to do that kind of thing, and I would do whatever I could within the constraints of funding to try to make sure it was allowed to happen. Finally, the member for Oxley raised the issue of people who are attempting to help job seekers but outside the ambit of the Job Network. I understand this issue. It does not just happen with indigenous people. There are a number of labour hire companies, for instance, that are outside the Job Network and who believe that they are sometimes subjected to unfair competition from Job Network members. There is nothing to stop anyone or any institution or agency that thinks it is able to deliver employment services from bidding to provide those under the Job Network. There will be a new Job Network tender in about two years timeless, in fact; I think in about 18 months time-but this issue of job matching payments and how we try to ensure fairness is certainly one that I have under review, one on which I do not believe we have necessarily reached the last word on optimal outcomes. So he makes a fair point. It is something that I am conscious of and something I hope the Job Network can tackle better in the years to come. I will finish with a remark that might apply to a number of the contributions that have been made by members opposite. I have a great deal of faith in the integrity of Job Network members. While they are only human and while it is true that junior Job Network member staff may well, life being what it is, sometimes get impatient with people, sometimes categorise people unfairly and sometimes perhaps write people off too soon, at the end of the day we have only a certain amount of resources and we need to invest them in the most sensible possible ways, and some job seekers are very hard to help. That does not mean that we should not do our absolute best, but it is right and proper that we should make intelligent decisions about the best way to invest those resources. I think that is best done at the local level by organisations that know the job seekers, know the communities and know the employment circumstances of those particular areas. Certainly I say to the member for Oxley and to anyone else in the parliament who is concerned about this: if you honestly believe that a particular constituent of yours is not getting a 28182 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 June 2001 fair go from the Job Network, talk to the relevant Job Network member, tell them that you think this individual is not getting a fair go and, if you do not think that the Job Network member has responded adequately, maybe talk to another Job Network member. If there is a problem with getting someone who is on Intensive Assistance with one institution, and is not getting on very well, transferred to a different agency, that is the sort of thing ministers can sometimes help with, and it is the sort of thing that departments can sometimes look at. Job seekers will do better and our society will be enriched if we have as much communication as possible. I accept that there will always be ideological and philosophical differences between governments and members of the opposition, but there is no reason whatsoever why we cannot come to good practical arrangements to the benefit of our own people. As I said, I would certainly encourage members opposite who believe that individuals are not getting a fair go to make contact with the Job Network, the department and, if necessary, my office and we will see what we can do to help. It covers the particular area I am interested in, and that is the Department of Environment and Heritage allocation in 2001-02 of $5 million. I quote the explanation: The Government will provide a grant of up to $5 million in 2001-02 to the Goondiwindi Town Council to develop a recreational facility at Serpentine Lagoon, Goondiwindi. The facility is needed because Boobera Lagoon is to be closed to current facilities as a result of a declaration of protection under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984. The new facility will satisfy relevant Commonwealth, state and local legislative requirements. I raise that and use it possibly as a vehicle for what I am going to say because I was very disturbed-not that I am denying these people the right to have this money allocated to them, even though I admit and acknowledge that it is in the seat of the Minister for Veterans’ Affairs, the Hon. Bruce Scott. I had an opportunity on Saturday, 9 June, with our council-the Fairfield City Council-and accompanied by the mayor, Councillor Robert Watkins, to launch a five-creek strategic plan in Fairfield. One may ask, ‘What are you doing launching a five-creek strategic plan in Fairfield City Council?’ After all, it is a metropolitan council so how has it got five creeks? Well, within our area we happen to have the Prospect Creek Catchment area, which covers approximately 98 square kilometres and includes the following five creeks: Prospect Creek, Orphan School Creek, Clear Paddock Creek, Green Valley Creek, Burns Creek and even part of Long Creek. There are something like 2,500 flood affected properties, and I will speak in another area of debate about that. But they are looking at the waterways, the catchments, sewer outfalls and modified and affected fauna habitat. I have brought it up because this council has been able to put a plan into place with no assistance whatsoever from this Commonwealth government. When we look at all the allocation of funds and all the uses for it, that one in particular, I believe, sticks out like a sore thumb. I am particularly proud of what the council have been able to do and I praise them for being such an innovative and progressive council, particularly where urban creek restoration is concerned. I was particularly pleased too that they brought in a cultural mapping group-a placebo art group-which is the first time it has ever been done, I understand, in an area such as ours. These people went to individual schools, factories, clubs or whatever that in any way, shape or form were involved in creeks and got the residents to come along and design with them what they, the residents, would like to see around the creeks in our area. speaker: Mrs Crosio (Prospect) (11.00 A.m.)
theText: I rise this morning to bring to the attention of theWednesday, 20 June 2001 MAIN COMMITTEE 28183 came to the forefront in the launching of the strategic plan-funding not provided by any government department but through the ratepayers and by the council itself. The strategic plan launched on that Saturday is part of an evolving approach for those five creeks and it is being seen and treated by our community as what we would like to see in the future. The creeks, we know, are changing all the time, and I believe this plan will continue to evolve and change. But I then wonder-and bring to the attention of the House-how much more could be done. I am using my council as an example because they at least have taken the bit between the teeth and have gone ahead and said, ‘Look, we have got an environment problem here. We have got a problem that needs fixing. We certainly applied to the relevant government departments for funding; that hasn’t been forthcoming, but our community is saying that more needs to be done.’ Possibly 100 years ago European settlers did all their boating and picnicking in this catchment creek area-and I should imagine that our first indigenous settlers used it as a lifeline to support themselves-and yet today we are seeing growth, pollutants and the degradation of a local environment area. A council is willing to start restoring it, but how much more could have been done if they had even a part of that $5 million that has been allocated to one lagoon. If we are realistically looking at allocating our taxpayers funds, let us look Australia wide as well. I could go on further about what is happening with the natural heritage allocations. People may ask, ‘Why didn’t you get some of that money?’ Well, that did not go too far in our area either, and there is certainly nothing I can point to in saying how great that is going to be as part of the contribution for an electorate like mine that probably has in the vicinity of 200,000 people and yet we are very limited as far as funds are concerned. I say to the Fairfield City Council and to their mayor: keep up the good work. To the staff and all those people who were involved in putting the strategic plan together, I say: you are to be commended and congratulated. I believe that this is the beginning of what we are going to be so very proud of in the future. More importantly, we have finally seen a local government area get together in saying, ‘We have a concern; we have a problem; let’s now start to rectify it and change it and, more importantly, change people’s perceptions of what our creeks are all about.’ (Time expired). this year’s budget for an extension of the Natural Heritage Trust. I said at the time of the budget that it appeared to be a smoke and mirrors exercise which appeared to shift money from other, established environment programs and re-badge them as new initiatives. Apart from the interest generated from the minimum legislated balance of the trust-that is $300 million-it is just not enough to even begin to tackle the $60 billion price tag that the National Farmers’ Federation and the Australian Conservation Council place on the repair bill for the Murray-Darling Basin alone. Unless we find alternative sources of funds to selling off Telstra, our environmental efforts are doomed to fail. I believe we need a levy such as that recently suggested by a committee of this parliament, as an environmental tax-let us be frank and call it what it is-and we need policies that seriously encourage investment in alternative energy. We cannot even commit to a Kyoto greenhouse target that we had already doubly exceeded by 1997-98. How absolutely pathetic is that, and what a betrayal of our future generations it is, if we do not put in place some meaningful targets and some meaningful long-term policies. I well remember in the debate during the sale of the first tranche of Telstra, the former shadow minister-later minister-Ian McLachlan was in the House, and I said then that the Murray-Darling Basin 2001 program was indeed a Murray-Darling Basin 2101 program, if we were going to be realistic about it. In a quiet chat afterwards with him he totally agreed.

theText: Much was made of the extra $1 billion set aside in28184 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 June 2001 That is the dimension of the program, and the challenge that we have ahead of us, in that sector of the Australian environment alone. If we are to be a clever nation and an innovative one, then we have an opportunity to apply it to the most pressing crisis that faces the globe. It is the environment, and Australia is ideally placed to be the engine room, if you like, of innovation in terms of environmental studies and environmental options. We do not even know what our supposed carrying capacity is in this country, and while there are many anxious to say we have got enough in this country, that we need to protect our environment, we must remember those millions of people who are on the subcontinent and China. Imagine once all the Chinese put down their bikes and hop into motor cars-which many of them will do in the next few years-what an enormous impact on our greenhouse contribution that will be. We really need to be quite objective about this. If it means that we do stretch our environmental capabilities in order to perhaps take pressure off elsewhere, we should look at that. We should look at what we need in terms of infrastructure to handle larger populations in regional Australia. But we should start doing it now, in a serious way, and not leave it for perhaps the next generation, the next term of parliament, the government after this or whatever it might be. Of course, the Australian public, not only us as legislators, as a parliament, have a role to play here. I notice in Ross Gittins’s article in the Herald today that Australians say the environment is important, but they are not prepared to even commit to green energy. I suggest part of this is a failure to understand how the existing industry can be a user of non-green resources and also be a promoter of green energy. It strikes me that there needs to be a completely separate supplier that the consumer can recognise as an independent broker of green energy and not one involved in chewing up our resources to create the non-green energy that we rely on. I know we rely on it, and we have to accept that. In my own small, modest way I am trying to encourage ADI in Lithgow. They assemble generators and equipment for wind power generation. (Extension of time granted) I know that ADI are involved in assembling wind power generators from overseas in one of their Victorian plants. I think it would be a very creative move for ADI, with government support and encouragement, to develop that technology in a place like Lithgow where we already have the beginnings of a wind power industry supported by the existing energy infrastructure in the area, to develop these alternative energies and the jobs, creativity and IT that go with them alongside our traditional energy sources-the coal mines. Then the children of the miners can move into the new energy that has to develop over the next couple of decades. If we do not do that, we will sit on our hands and leave our kids with an environment that I know my young fellow, at 19 or 20, agonises over-not as an activist or anything else-as to what we can do to turn the ship of old energy around and to really do something positive. He believes-and I certainly do-that Australia is in a prime position to create that expertise. April on my concerns about the level of greenhouse gas emissions. I have spoken about climate change-in short, global warming-and the failure of the government to deal appropriately with the Kyoto protocol because of the position of the United States government, primarily President George Bush. It was very heartening for environmentalists to view the images which came to our screens last week, when President Bush travelled to Europe, and the outrage that was expressed by Europeans on behalf of all people on this planet who have grave concerns about the level of greenhouse gas emissions that are being spewed out on mother earth on a daily basis. The Australian government should be taking a greater stand against the position of the United States. I do not believe that Senator Hill is doing enough. speaker: Mr Murphy (Lowe) (11.12 A.m.)
theText: I spoke in the House on 26 March and again on 2Wednesday, 20 June 2001 MAIN COMMITTEE 28185 than the environment. Quite honestly, if you do not have an environment, you do not have an economy. Global warming is the most serious environmental issue facing us today and Australia should be showing greater leadership in speaking out against the behaviour of President Bush. I have wondered many times what would have happened had Al Gore won the last election. Al Gore is a very outspoken environmentalist who has grave concerns for the future of this planet. Unfortunately, he missed out on being elected as President of the United States of America. It seems that Mr Bush’s cabinet is stacked with oil, lead and aluminium business executives who are motivated only by economic imperatives and not by the consequences of global warming on the environment. I take this opportunity to send a strong message on behalf of the many constituents in my electorate of Lowe who have expressed grave reservations about the weak-kneed approach of Senator Hill in not standing up to President Bush. He should be encouraged to take a tougher stand. Unless more countries take on the United States in the interests of saving the planet, as obviously the Europeans are prepared to do, the United States of America will continue to be concerned only with economic imperatives and we would all pay a great price for that. Dr STONE (Murray-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage) (11.16 a.m.)-In summing up the debate, I thank the members for Calare, Lowe and Prospect for their contributions. It is very important that we consider that this government’s environmental credentials are under scrutiny, both domestically and internationally, just as all governments’ environmental credentials and investments now are. We have a new consciousness that, for the first time in history, there are more environmental refugees around the globe than there are refugees created by war. That is the case for the first time in human history. We see water resources running down or being polluted across the globe, and we see issues like climate change through human intervention, which is a very serious issue and is now acknowledged to be something that all nations must address most urgently. I will come to the issue of climate change that the member for Lowe and the member for Calare addressed. To begin with the member for Prospect’s contribution, she was concerned about the five-creek strategic plan in her electorate. It sounds like a very commendable plan, and I add my congratulations to hers for an effort well done by her councils. She was concerned that they were going it alone, so to speak-that they did not seem to have been tapping into Natural Heritage Trust funding. Let me say to her that we have been very conscious of urban environments and the degradation of water supplies, air quality and noise abatement. There is a whole range of urban environmental issues that the Natural Heritage Trust specifically identified and addressed. In the vast majority of cases the natural resource issues that we have to address are in regional and remote Australia, but there are, too, of courseMrs Crosio-In marginal seats, more like it. funding, including urban Waterwatch, under the Living Cities program. The Commonwealth announced in the 2000-01 budget statement an amount of over $12 million over three years for the urban Waterwatch program in order to improve the health of urban waterways through community monitoring in urban areas. As a result of budget requirements, the urban Waterwatch component of the Living Cities program was reallocated. I say to the councils who are involved with the five-creek strategic plan that they should talk to Environment Australia and explore those specific NHT programs. They should also talk to Environment Australia, to me specifically or to DETYA about Green Corps. We have put $88.8 million into the Green Corps program across Australia. A significant number of those wonderful young Australians, aged between 17 and 20, who are involved in Green Corps work in urban catchments, just like the catchment the member for Prospect described.

I think the NFF-ACF estimated $3.7 billion a year for 10 years as a minimum. The point of course is that this government have put more funding specifically into environmental repair and natural resource conservation and protection than any other government in the history of Australia. We began in 1996, needing to look at where to find those funds since we inherited a deficit, as the member for Calare would be only too aware, and we were able to have a win-win situation by partially privatising Telstra and using those funds to retire a lot of inherited debt and to invest in the Natural Heritage Trust. The good news is that, by very careful management of our economy, the Howard government are now able to go beyond simply relying on the proceeds of sale of some assets. With five years of surplus budgets we have now been able to draw our environmental funding from consolidated revenue. That is exactly how we hoped it would be, but we could not wait until we got the deficit down before we were able to commit billions of dollars. We could not wait for the surplus; hence, we began in 1996, as we did. The member for Calare was concerned that, as he said, we do not even know what the carrying capacity of the country is. We could have waited five years for the National Land and Water Resources Audit to do that base study work-we are now beginning to get excellent outcomes from the investment in their research and development; they have just recently produced audits of salinity and water quality in our country-but we felt that we could not wait five years for that work to be done, so we commenced in 1996 understanding the scale of the problem and understanding the level of expenditure that needed to be undertaken as soon as possible. We are doing two things: we are investing in on-the-ground work to make sure our agricultural production is sustainable and our natural resources protected and, at the same time, we are doing that research and development work that is needed so we can monitor and assess what we have achieved and whether we are heading in the right direction so we can understand the scope and the scale of the problem that is with us now and which is going to continue as we continue to be naturally resource based in many parts of our economy. The member for Lowe was understandably concerned, like most Australians, about the issue of climate change and how our government is responding to our responsibilities as one of the world’s highest per capita emitters of carbon. speaker: Dr Stone
theText: Please come and knock on my door as well because, as parliamentary secreWednesday, 20 June 2001 MAIN COMMITTEE 28187 is an issue that requires international cooperation, and the difficulty is now with a USA administration which does not share the same level of commitment to Kyoto that was exhibited in the previous administration. Our country, Australia, leads the world in dedication of funds to greenhouse gas abatement. We have the world’s first national greenhouse office. We have put over a billion dollars into long-term work which includes research into alternative energy sources and helping industry commercialise alternative energy technologies. The member for Calare will be interested in that too, because that was one of his concerns. We are very realistic and, as our minister has said in the Senate in response to questions about how we are going to cope with the fact that the United States is not as concerned about progressing the Kyoto agreement as the previous administration, we are acknowledging that it is going to be very difficult. We are continuing to support the Kyoto protocol moving forward and being accepted. (Extension of time granted) In particular, we are concerned that developing countries participate in identifying the issues and finding solutions to the problem because we know that in the very near future developing countries will have significantly more emissions than developed countries. We are in the process of further negotiation on the implementation of the protocol. There is no go-slow; there is no sitting on our hands. We are pressing forward as hastily as we can, given the current political circumstances that are in the community of those addressing these problems. I am very proud that it was our government, the Australian government, that put on the table at Kyoto discussions on the issue of vegetation: the significance of carbon sequestration and carbon sinks using vegetation. That was one of the first serious discussions about the role of vegetation and its retention, in that global forum, and now Australia is very much respected for the work that we have done in that regard. I think Senator Hill needs to be commended for the work that he is doing. Certainly our government has put our money where our mouth is in terms of significant commitment to the Australian Greenhouse Office and the range of programs that go with that. In conclusion, let me say that Australia has a very significant problem as a consequence of the last 250 or so years of management of our natural resources. They have not always led to the most sustainable outcomes. We understand that. We are learning, now, how to manage this country in a way so that our future generations are not going to inherit a degraded water supply or air pollution standards which leave many sick with asthma. We understand the needs of our Bureau of Meteorology. That has been significantly funded in an ongoing fashion. We understand our responsibilities in the Antarctic. We are one of the first countries in the world to have an oceans policy and to persist in making sure that our endangered species are protected. Therefore, I am proud to be a part of the Howard government that has been, as I said, the first in the history of Australia to commit the level of funding that now is dedicated to the environment. I am quite sure that the community of Australia is with us in understanding that this level of investment is essential for our futures. Trust and the Howard government’s initiative in repairing the environment and how significant that has been in the electorate of Mitchell. speaker: Mr Cadman (Mitchell) (11.28 A.m.)
theText: I want to raise the issue of the Natural Heritage28188 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 June 2001 As the development of Sydney presses out into the Hawkesbury valley, we are finding that there is increasing pressure on the environment. Greater care is needed to ensure the health of the Hawkesbury River, to make sure that the blue-green algae bloom that occurs on a fairly regular basis in that river is contained, that fish life is preserved and that the water quality in the Hawkesbury is retained. Unfortunately, a recent decision by Mr Amery, the state minister, to abandon the main funding mechanism, the Hawkesbury-Nepean Catchment Management Trust, means that there is no organisation that is capable of receiving the funds and making decisions on resource allocation as to how the federal government should apply the Natural Heritage Trust funds. I do not know how it is going to work. The decision by Amery to wipe out this organisation, which was established by my colleague Mr Kevin Rozzoli, was incredible. It is an organisation which has served the people of Western Sydney extremely well. It has focused on water quality retention and it drew together instrumentalities such as the water board and five or six local government bodies which have fought and failed to take action to retain or improve the health of the river. In fact, Mr Amery, with one stroke of the pen, dismissed this group. Mrs Crosio interjectingtalking about the destruction of the environment of the Hawkesbury and Nepean rivers. I stand alongside my colleagues in the state house who seek an inquiry as to why this organisation has been disbanded. You have left the Commonwealth without any mechanism to fund or make priorities in that area. The member who has interrupted is from Western Sydney. She knows jolly well there is no replacement body. She knows that to fund Penrith City Council, Hawkesbury City Council or those sorts of bodies is a piecemeal approach. She knows that the Hawkesbury-Nepean Catchment Management Trust was the only body capable of administering these funds and making the right priority decisions. It is a most appalling decision. I believe that there should be an upper house inquiry. I appeal to the parliamentary secretary to use her powers of persuasion with her state colleagues. We will certainly, from this level, be seeing what alternative funding processes can be used. I believe an inquiry should be conducted to assess the impact of the trust’s closure on the environment, the effectiveness of the trust’s work in improving the health of the catchment and whether government activities have affected the trust’s functions. I suspect that the trust has been critical of the government’s decision to expand development and housing on the former ADI site. The trust says this is environmental sacrilege and it should never happen. The trust has been sacked because it opposed the development policies of the New South Wales government. speaker: Mrs Crosio (Prospect) (11.37 A.m.)
theText: There are a number of issues I would like to raise28190 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 June 2001 unfair that a road that is going to be built in Western Sydney is going to have a toll while other so-called national highways do not. Another area of concern with the orbital-I put a submission in on this because an environmental impact statement was issued-was Horsley Drive, which goes right through the centre of my electorate. That was originally classified as a road that was only going to be a feeder road in the future, but the traffic volumes indicated by the EIS show that when the orbital is built off Wallgrove Drive, Horsley Drive east of the proposal will have a 51 per cent increase in traffic over the volume of traffic now using it. If anyone cares to use that road during what is classified as a busy time, particularly coming to the Cumberland Highwaygoing east or then going west-they will find that between the hours of 7 a.m. to 9.30 a.m. and 4 p.m. to 5.30 or 6 p.m. it is actually a parking station: we cannot move on it now. There is no money allocated or even a desire at this stage to make that a four-lane expressway to feed these tollways or orbital roads. This is a residential road and it is going to go right through an area where certainly the council does not have the responsibility but I know the state government does. I am not worrying so much about the funding for that but I am concerned about traffic volume. In fact, people have always been told that that was going to be an internal feeder road throughout the municipality, which is now the city, and that it certainly would not be affected by any future expansions. In the minister’s own words, that is now going to happen. I am also a little disturbed about the government’s ownership of the Badgerys Creek site. In answer to my question on notice-and in answer to a question on notice from my colleague the member for Lowe, who, I am sure, will have more to say about it-the minister said: The Government has decided to retain ownership of the Badgerys Creek site and to legislate to protect the site from incompatible development in surrounding areas which may prejudice its future use as an airport. The Government will further review Sydney’s airport needs in 2005. No site other than Badgerys Creek is currently being considered for a second major airport. That answer was given on 4 June 2001. I find that answer rather disconcerting when we realise now, when they are looking for the sale of Sydney airport, that they are going to have carte blanche as to whether they go ahead and build another airport, wherever it may be. Why aren’t the government honest with the people of Western Sydney? They are saying, ‘We will not have further use for that site; therefore, we are not going to require that site,’ but people in my electorate will not take that as an answer. As far as they are concerned, all we have done with Badgerys Creek is put it on hold. More importantly, we do not seem to be looking at the overall problem of what is happening in New South Wales as far as transport and transport studies go. I want to touch on that very briefly so I will come back to it later. I also want to touch on the Roads to Recovery program again. I raised this in the House in December of last year when it was reported in the papers that money being allocated to Western Sydney-$13-odd million-was all going to the electorate of Prospect. (Extension of time granted) I must admit that when I read the $13.2 million was all going to go to the electorate of Prospect, I grabbed the paper and ran round the table. However, when I looked further, I saw that it was not going to the electorate of Prospect at all. It was going to be shared by the electorates of eight colleagues and about four different councils. So the one bit of money was being recorded in the electorates of the members for Chifley, Reid, Lindsay and Greenway, in my electorate and, dare I say, in part of Parramatta and Strathfield. So when we are talking about this $13.2 million from the Roads to Recovery program that was to be expended in Western Sydney, I can assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that there was very little we got of that. Wednesday, 20 June 2001 MAIN COMMITTEE 28191 In the allocation here today, I would also like to touch on flooding and flood mitigation programs. I want to bring up the flooding because of what we saw happen in 1996. When this government came to power, they set up a National Commission of Audit and used that as the excuse to cut $80 million out of all flood mitigation and urban, rural and regional communities’ programming. I understand that after intensive lobbying, probably again from some of the marginal seats, a much weaker regional flood mitigation program was reintroduced in 1999. But you have to look a bit further than that. It was reintroduced in the rural areas with much fanfare but only $20 million was put back into it over three years, again into rural towns and regional centres. I am not saying that the need is not great there, but not one penny has been allocated to urban flood mitigation programs in Western Sydney. I am glad the member for Parramatta is here, because he put out a press release stating that certain flood mitigation funding was coming to the seat of Parramatta. Of course, being ever observant, I was ready to scream, ‘Why is that money going to one particular urban area and not to the other?’ only to find that it was just a misrepresentation on the member for Parramatta’s behalf, that the money did not go there at all, that he was looking at all of this so-called extra funding coming in. Of course, it was not the case. We had the member for Mitchell talking about what is happening to the Hawkesbury River and to the catchment program there. Of course, he did not want to acknowledge who actually set it up and how it was funded. Under the Keating government, the previous Labor government, we had flood mitigation programs going on what we called 2:2:1-in other words, for every $2 from the Commonwealth, $2 was supplied by the state and $1 by local councils. That has been completely wiped. Forget that many local councils and areas like mine have $30 million worth of flood mitigation work still outstanding. I represent three particular council areas that are massively inundated when flooding occurs. Just recently, with the showers that we had, two schools had to close in my electorate. I am talking about the Patrician Brothers, which had to close its school and 1,500 kids were sent home. Shops were inundated and they had to close the doors. It all comes from urban flood mitigation problems. Councils are continuing to work on this. They are still at least getting cooperation from the state government, but there is not one cent coming any more from this federal government. If we are talking about needs and responsibilities, with respect to the heritage funding, the parliamentary secretary who spoke previously talked about paving new ways of doing things and going in new directions. I say: what was wrong with some of the old directions? If you want a job done, what is wrong with bringing state and local government money into it? If you want a job done in the urban areas, then certainly it needs Commonwealth funding. There are some tremendous problems happening now because of the residential build-up in areas. In fact, when I spoke previously about the environment and creeks, one of the reasons we are looking at using another method to clear floodways and clean up the creek system is to assist and help in flood mitigation programs. It boils down to the fact that flooding comes without warning. If we do not take action prior to flooding, then for the people who are going to be affected in the long term, it is going to be a lot more costly to overcome. In our area we have been raising houses so that they are above the flood mitigation levels. People could say that in the fifties and sixties they should never have been given consent to build there, but try to tell that to people when they have bought their land in good faith and they have built their house on it. What we are doing there in regard to flood mitigation is to raise those houses so that at least people’s lives and properties are not damaged when those creeks flood. This is part of the Georges River and Prospect Creek management. 28192 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 June 2001 We have not had one penny allocated by this government since they came to power in 1996, following that national audit excuse which was used to cut out the $80 million funding. It is all very well to have lobbying by rural and regional areas, even though they are getting a paltry amount of money-$20 million over three years is not going to fix one iota of the concerns and problems that rural and regional centres have.
