theText: It will indeed, and it will only happen with the cooperation of state govWednesday, 20 June 2001 MAIN COMMITTEE 28195 “The Government has missed this golden opportunity to build on last year’s Roads to Recovery initiative. Indeed, the forward estimates released today show that by 2004-2005, total road funding will fall by 25% in real terms,” ... At the beginning of this year the Mayor of the City of Lake Macquarie wrote to me seeking my support for Commonwealth government funding approval for the integrated transport strategy, under the Roads to Recovery program. He stated: Lake Macquarie is the largest regional centre North of Sydney, and acts in a pivotal role as the gateway to the Hunter. This project will provide an important part of an essential arterial route, to improve connections from the Hunter Region’s largest employment zone, to the National Highway and the Port of Newcastle. The Newcastle and Hunter Business Chamber views the project as one of regional significance within their regional infrastructure Strategic Plan, and therefore have endorsed the project. I wrote to the minister at the table supporting this proposal and the application for funding under the program. The council applied specifically for funding for a project under the Roads of National Importance program. The Lake Macquarie City Council has proposed an integrated transport strategy as an important infrastructure project for the Hunter region and is seeking Commonwealth funding assistance. It has also proposed that funding of $26 million will come from the New South Wales government and $1.4 million from council. The funding for the planning of the new railway station and transport interchange was announced in the New South Wales state budget. The project is a major infrastructure development for the Hunter region and will generate job growth, improve access to public transport and provide environmental benefits for Lake Macquarie. In the past 10 years in excess of 1,000 new employment positions have been created in Lake Macquarie, most within the Cardiff Industrial Park in my electorate of Charlton. It is proposed that the estate be expanded and further developed. The industrial area houses major transport firms, such as John Farragher Transport and Logistics, and Powerdown Australia, a major manufacturer and exporter of bus chassis. However, businesses are hindered by treacherous and inefficient road links to the F3 freeway. Lake Macquarie City Council’s proposed integrated transport strategy will alleviate this problem. The Hunter region has suffered significantly following the closure of BHP and the downturn in our manufacturing industry. I believe this proposal will greatly assist the maintenance and extension of employment opportunities in the region. I supported the application for funding under the Roads to Recovery program for the Lake Macquarie integrated transport centre and I recommended it to the minister for his favourable consideration. The City of Lake Macquarie is one of the fastest growing areas in New South Wales. It is centred on Australia’s largest coastal lake and is flanked by both mountains and the Pacific Ocean. It has unique environmental and economic potential to become one of the most desirable areas in which to live in Australia. As the city’s role as a major urban and tourism centre develops, our challenge is to realise this potential by providing and improving facilities to encourage and facilitate economic growth within the Hunter region. Today, its population of 185,000 and work force of 96,000 are major economic drivers in the Hunter region. The Lake Macquarie integrated transport centre is an infrastructure project that addresses job creation, improves road safety and increases public transport accessibility for a large proportion of Lake Macquarie and western Newcastle residents, and provides improved access to the national highway and the port of Newcastle. I understand that the mayor and the general manager of the city met with Senator Ian Macdonald earlier this year and held discussions with him. However, we are yet to get a response from the minister about the funding of this nationally important project. 28196 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 June 2001 particular, the $80 million which has been allocated to the F3 freeway. I am very pleased that the Deputy Prime Minister is in the chamber today, and I record the thanks of the thousands of Central Coast commuters who regularly use the F3 freeway. It is the main road transport link between the Central Coast and Sydney. I heard the member opposite speaking about the rapidly expanding area of Lake Macquarie, and, of course, for that area the only main road transport link to Sydney is the F3. When I was first elected to parliament in 1996, I was shocked to hear that the previous Labor government had done absolutely no forward planning with regard to the F3, despite the fact that it was the most heavily trafficked road in New South Wales and that it was obvious that the surrounding areas were expanding rapidly. SoI was behind the eight ball when I was elected. I made a commitment to the people of the Central Coast that I would do everything I could to ensure that funding was made available. Certainly, when the coalition government were elected we found that there was virtually no money in the bank. We had to address the huge deficit that the Labor Party had left us. We worked hard on that, and now we can start to return some of that money to the Australian community in the form of better roads through the Roads to Recovery program in projects such as the F3. I have to record my anger with, and disgust at, some of the actions of the New South Wales government in relation to this funding. Firstly, their roads minister, Mr Scully, when we announced this money, said ‘Oh well, it’s not enough; there should be more.’ Then he had the audacity to say that the money was not available now and would not be available until 2004. The money is available today. If the RTA can get their act together, can get their planning done and can get their costings done, we can start widening the freeway by the end of the year. But the Labor Party continue this campaign of misinformation. Only today I have received a letter that a constituent received from the Labor Party candidate in Robertson who continues this myth that the money is not available and that it will not be available until 2002 or 2004. It is totally untrue. Already the Deputy Prime Minister has written to the New South Wales government assuring them that that money is available. In fact, on 24 May 2001 the Prime Minister wrote to the Premier of New South Wales, Bob Carr. I will read some of that letter into Hansard: My dear PremierI am writing to you concerning Commonwealth funding for widening of the F3 Freeway between the Hawkesbury River and Calga. It is reported that the NSW Minister for Transport, the Hon Carl Scully MP, has claimed that the Commonwealth Government is holding up funding for this project. These reported statements by Mr Scully refer to the absence of Commonwealth allocation to the F3 for 2001-02. I am advised that the absence of an allocation in the coming year reflects advice from the NSW Roads and Traffic Authority that commencement of the widening project would need to await substantial planning and environmental assessment work. In relation to this, I would point out that the Commonwealth has today received a request from the RTA for preconstruction funding of $2 million in 2001-02 and this has been approved pending submission of a formal project proposal report. The last paragraph of this letter could not be clearer. This is from the Prime Minister of Australia to Premier Carr: I wish to assure you that the Commonwealth funding of $80 million will flow as soon as construction starts. If it starts this year, funding will flow this year. I would ask therefore that you instruct your transport Minister to begin construction work by the end of this calendar year.

theText: On MondayI spoke in the House during the griev28200 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 June 2001 Lowe, should it be elected. That showed quite clearly what the flight paths would be. The candidate from the coalition, a member of the Liberal Party, said that this was not a Liberal Party policy-which has been shown to be false-and that the Liberal Party had the answers and that they would halve the number of planes flying over Lowe. We know that that is not the case. Very shortly after the Howard government was elected in 1996, in August 1996, the Airports Bill went through parliament. There was bipartisan support for the future sale of Sydney airport, but that was conditional on fixing the problems associated with aircraft noise. (Extension of time granted) That meant the implementation of the long-term operating plan and also a decision to be made at a future time to build a second airport for Sydney, to take the pressure off Kingsford Smith Airport. When the bill was debated in the parliament, Minister Sharp, who was in the job at that time, promised to fix the aircraft noise problems associated with Kingsford Smith Airport, and also foreshadowed the future construction of a second airport for the people of Sydney. We have subsequently learned that that debate was all about an expectation that whoever purchased that 50-year lease for Sydney airport would only have an option to build a second airport. The clear understanding, by all people who had been associated with the debate, was that the agreement to the sale of Sydney airport was on the clear understanding that a second airport would be built. That is what people effectively meant. It would appear, certainly from the campaign I have run by placing questions on the Notice Paper to try to get answers, that the government is in a position to effectively run away from the commitment to build a Sydney west airport-which is Badgerys Creek-in the foreseeable future. Why are they doing this? They are doing it simply to maximise the sale price of Sydney airport. The lease sale price, as I understand it from various reports, is about $4 billion. If the government were to require the purchaser of that lease to also build a Sydney West airport, no doubt the sale price for Sydney airport would be significantly less than $4 billion. Obviously, in this whole debate about resolving the aircraft noise problem for the people of Sydney the government are more concerned with the economic imperatives of maximising the sale price for Sydney airport and accommodating the vested and sectional interests that want to see Sydney airport stay where it is. The grave concern for my electorate, Minister, is that the expansion of Sydney airport by effectively making Bankstown airport an overflow airport-a de facto second airport, if you like-for the people of Sydney has disastrous consequences for people of the inner west, particularly my electorate. If you maximise Sydney airport you will slowly see a return to parallel runway operations and we know what the PRM is all about. The western end of my electorate will suffer because of the increased air traffic from Bankstown airport. It is a very serious issue for the people of Lowe. I asked you a question, Minister, on the notice paper on 28 March-and thank you for your reply of 7 June 2001. The answer you provided was: The government has introduced the long-term operating plan to address Sydney airport’s noise issues. A country railroad in the electorate of, perhaps, the member for Hinkler loses a couple of million and everybody in this country goes ape. Yet we spend billions and billions of dollars subsidising roads and road transport companies in this country and we do not seem to blink one eyelid. The debate loses a considerable deal because we do not look at all the imperatives and all the impacts of funding for rail or road. For example, a recent German study showed quite clearly that if you invested a billion deutschmarks on rail, road or light rail there would be very different impacts in terms of an employment dividend. If you invest in roads, you get about 10,000 to 12,000 jobs; if you invest in heavy rail, you get about 22,000 jobs. If you invest in light rail, you get about 24,000 jobs. Maybe that is an issue that the minister ought to take on board-as should, particularly, his department, which has a particularly narrow view of anything other than road transport. I would like to make one comment about this budget: $600 million has gone towards company cars and subsidies for transport rigs. I think the minister’s own group, the Australian Rail Track Corporation, has shown that, if you spent $500 million or $600 million on rail instead of transport rigs or company cars, you could shift two or three million tonnes of freight off our roads and onto rail. It would be far more efficient, with a better employment dividend, and much better for the country. The subsidy for roads in this country amounts to billions and billions. It is a hidden subsidy, one that is forgotten in any debate-freight insurance, hospitalisation, road trauma, road maintenance, the list goes on and on and on. I am not suggesting that we should not invest in roads. That would be a stupid point of view to put forward. It became very apparent to me, as I looked at what had happened internationally and listened to the players here, that for commercial reasons-the aviation industry seeking to meet the needs of its customers-people would not use another airport for a very long time into the future. The airline companies would adopt what are euphemistically known in the industry as coping strategies, which is to say that they would rearrange their schedules so that some flights overflew Sydney, in other cases there would be a rationalisation of the number of small planes, running effectively shuttle services between Sydney and other capitals-all sorts of measures would be used to avoid having to use other airports for as long as possible into the future, at least for the next decade. theText: It should be 100 per cent.28212 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 June 2001 is actually the highest level of freight support of any similar rail length in the world today. It is actually the highest; it is much higher than it was. The cost has come down and the transport times have come down with a surprisingly modest investment in track. It is a good model and we ought to pursue it. As the member for Hinkler said, the next major step-it is really quite logical if you stop to think about it-is the north-south freight corridor between Melbourne and Brisbane and the points between and beyond. It has about 10 per cent of the freight task at the moment. An audit report by the ARTC was commissioned after the very valuable reports that had come from the private sector and from this place. They were valuable reports and I thank those responsible for them. We commissioned the audit report by the Australian Rail Track Corporation to have a close look at how we ought to rearrange these things. They again identified the need for more money but said that, until you get the management structures right and the management issues sorted out, you are not going to get the traffic volumes that you want. The key issue is unquestionably getting the New South Wales Carr government to get serious about track access, signalling and consistency of arrangements. I do not say that as a partisan remark because there are other governments of both persuasions that have helped us to secure seamless interstate track operations, but we need them on the north-south corridor. I urge those opposite, in the spirit of bipartisanship, to help us do everything we can to get the New South Wales government, which for various reasons is pretty focused on what is happening with its passenger transport network around Sydney, sorted out. We have had money on the table now for a couple of years, for a dedicated freight line through Sydney, and nothing has happened. In the last budget I pulled that back, and we put it into Australian Rail Track Corporation instead, and said that they are to fund it only on the basis of improvements in management and access arrangements. I think there are all sorts of very sound reasons why we need to be rejuvenating rail. Energy conservation is one and greenhouse is another, but there are all sorts of other efficiencies: congestion in the capital city ports and what have you. All of those are very sound reasons for supporting the redevelopment and expansion of rail in this country. I think that broadly covers the major issues that were raised. I notice fuel excise mentioned again-I always think that, if you want to enter the debate and make some critical comments, you have a lot more credibility if you acknowledge the good work that was done first, and in relation to fuel excise several things need to be acknowledged. One is that we have dramatically reduced the fuel excise on transport, including rail. It has all gone. We have actually taken the excise off rail, and that is a very worthwhile reform. (Extension of time granted) I think I heard the member for the Northern Territory say that he thought the trucking industry was an efficient and important industry, and he praised them up. They of course very much welcome what we have done in abolishing sales tax and indirect taxation burdens on their industry. It has made a very big difference, particularly in areas like the Northern Territory which are freight export oriented, and in which freight costs can impose real difficulties on local communities. In addition, it needs to be remembered that we have dedicated something like $900 million to rural and remote areas to offset the impact of the GST on petrol prices. theText: Through you, Madam Chair, could you ask the Deputy Prime Minister28214 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 June 2001 As is my custom in these things, I will check the figures of the honourable member for the Northern Territory and I will seek to respond to him. Minister: at Milikapiti, under the old regime, excise was 44.137c a litre, which you will recall. Under the new regime it is 38.14c a litre currently, and extra GST is 10.37c. Whichever way the Deputy Prime Minister tries to portray it-I accept that fuel excise has come down, I accept that you have abolished indexation, I accept all of that; that is not my query-my query is why should people in the Northern Territory and people who live in high cost areas pay more as a result of the GST for goods and services than other Australians? In this case it happens to be fuel. Can you answer that question? Why should people in my electorate, who are, as I repeat, amongst the poorest of Australians with some of the highest costs of living, when they drive to and from work or into town, in a case such as that of Milikapiti be required to pay so much more for their fuel as a result of the GST than other people in Australia? That is a simple question; it should receive a simple answer. The thing has to be viewed in totality; that is the first point I would make. You mentioned they were paying something like 40c in excise per litre. I think you will find that about 32c of that was imposed by the Labor Party. I will check the figures and I will come back you, but you have to view taxation imposts and the burden in any specific area in the totality of the taxation and other financial frameworks that pertain to that community. Tax reform was very much needed in the interests of rural and regional Australia. I make no apologies for saying that. I believe that rural and regional Australia is better off for it. There is the reality that some types of taxes will accumulate a little more in some areas than in others, but I have noticed, on average, a closing of the country-city price differential in recent times. You can always find examples where it has gone the other way. If they are excessive, we can have them looked at, but I will respond in full when I have checked out the figures in the claims. speaker: Mr Mcmullan (Fraser) (4.06 P.m.)
theText: I want to speak particularly about the arts aspectWednesday, 20 June 2001 MAIN COMMITTEE 28215 My concern is that the knowledge nation of the 21st century requires not only those aspects that are commonly referred to, such as science, engineering and research and development; in the 21st century content is king. The countries which are producing the content that will drive the information technology and other products of the 21st century will be the countries which succeed. And that requires encouragement of the creative people in our community, protection of their intellectual property, incentive for them to produce, and a climate in which they feel respected, acknowledged, appreciated and encouraged. All of that is lacking in this budget. I have made those comments before but I repeat them because it is a source of great disappointment to me. I want today to deal with some specific matters. I hope that the Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation, when he arrives, will be able to respond to some of these specific matters. I want first to deal with the issue of contemporary music. I am extremely concerned that there is nothing in this budget for contemporary music except cuts. In 1998, the government was under pressure on the issue of contemporary music in the lead-up to the election because of its disastrous decision about parallel importation of CDs and its consequences for young artists and Australian recording companies. It was under pressure, the arts community was campaigning, and it responded by throwing in $10 million. It is very typical of this government, in the lead-up to an election, under pressure, to decide to provide taxpayers’ funds to bail out problems it has created. So it provided a $10 million fund for contemporary music export, to assist business planning and market development, the development of an online strategy, specific programs for particular states, a contemporary music touring program and community broadcasting. That $10 million program runs out on 30 June this year. To continue, it needed funding in this budget, and there was not one cent. It was an unannounced, unheralded $10 million cut in support for contemporary music, which is the art form of the young generation of creative Australians that young Australians listen to and enjoy. The most important loss to the contemporary music industry will be the touring program that used to be operated through Playing Australia. The disappointment that this program was not continued was best summed up by the Music Managers Forum, which labelled the abandonment of the contemporary music touring program with disappointment and regret and said: The government must acknowledge that despite a huge financial windfall from the music industry, its reciprocal reinvestment in the sector and its commitment to the development of a valid powerful youth culture is minimal. This industry faces the continuing impact of parallel importation, but the compensation package is gone. It is once again typical of this government. It is like the GST. The GST continues forever, but the compensation is only temporary. (Extension of time granted) The contemporary music industry will continue to be hit by this flawed policy with regard to parallel imports, but the compensation package has been eliminated. The cynics amongst us might suggest that the government’s plan is to allow this to lapse so that, come the election, they can announce it again and it will be a new policy. It is called filling in the hole you dug for yourself and calling it progress. So they have dug a $10 million hole for the contemporary music industry. I would be pleased if they went to the election offering to fill it in again, but I am very doubtful. WhatI am really concerned about is the future of the contemporary music touring program. Will the government commit to it again? AmI right in assuming that it has been abolished? If it has been abolished, what assistance is there for the contemporary music industry? I await advice from the minister. That example is being painfully followed by the book industry now. The book industry knows exactly the two problems the contemporary music industry faces: one, the threat of 28216 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 June 2001 parallel imports; and, two, the risk that the damage to their industry will continue while the compensation package gets eroded. We are having a debate on a bill in this parliament at the moment about the extension of the parallel importation principles of the book industry. There have been some, not surprisingly, eloquent critiques of that by some of our great Australian writers, such as Frank Moorehouse, who appeared before the Senate committee and in a very devastating manner illustrated the flaws in the government’s approach and the threat to young Australian writers and Australian publishers if this flawed policy is continued. The book industry knows the nature of this government’s attitude. It already feels threatened because of what it has seen happen to contemporary music. The industry is not being offered any compensation for the impact of parallel importation, but it is aware that it has already been severely hit by the GST. It was offered a compensation package in return for that, but just like the parallel importation effect, the GST is in forever but it is not sure how long the compensation package will last. There is no compensation for the book industry for the threat that it faces from parallel imports. SoI am really concerned that this government continues to attack the arts. It attacks the fundamental basis of intellectual property protection and the capacity of creative Australians to earn income from their intellectual property. It does not just affect artists; it is also true in the software industry-but that is not my brief for today; I have spoken about that elsewhere. All of those people feel that their capacity to earn income from their creativity is under threat by this government. What is the 21st century about? It is about countries gaining income from their ideas, from their brainpower. So this government puts in place policies to make it impossible. The third thing I want to talk about is the cynical exercise by the government with regard to the Young and Emerging Artists Initiative and the Major Festivals Initiative-two proposals introduced by the government in 1998 with great fanfare. In the budget, they announced renewed support for them. But, if you read the fine print for those two programs, this renewed support means they have got 12 months to live: they are on death row. They will be abolished straight after the election. They have not been abolished now because young Australians resent enough the attack on the contemporary music industry. They do not want to see their new and emerging artists program attacked as well. But they are under threat. The only salvation might be that same cynical view that the government are merely withdrawing funding in this budget so that nobody can plan-the major festivals are in crisis-so they can emerge and make an announcement at the election to say, ‘Aren’t we clever? We are proposing to fill in the hole we just dug. We will renew these two programs if we are re-elected.’ But major project planning takes longer than that and this is a disastrous approach. (Extension of time granted) I assure others here that this will be my last extension because I know others wish to have a chance to speak. There are many other matters that I wish to raise but, having spoken about my concern about the general problem in the budget and with this government, of lack of commitment to the arts and creativity and my concern about contemporary music, the book industry, the Young and Emerging Artists Initiative and the Major Festivals Initiative, I want to turn briefly to the ABC. Like many other Australians, I am extremely concerned about the lack of Australian drama on ABC Television. The amount of BBC reruns such as Yes, Minister, Fawlty Towers, One Foot in the Grave is now beyond a joke. As much as I may have enjoyed some of those programs when they were first run-and I quite enjoyed them the second, and I did not mind them even in the third-I really got a bit disappointed recently to see at the end of a Yes, Minister program, when they have the credits at the end that the copyright was dated 1975. A terWednesday, 20 June 2001 MAIN COMMITTEE 28217 ries told by their fellow Australians, creating jobs and opportunity for creative Australians to produce programs and participate in programs, write music, act, write scripts, produce, direct and provide their technical expertise, it produces nothing. Australians should be able to turn on the ABC and hear their own stories. Of course, there are alarming allegations-and I would like the minister to assure the Main Committee that this is not true-that the ABC was bidding for the rights for The Weakest Link and that one of the reasons why Gail Jarvis was dismissed was that she was unsuccessful in winning the rights to The weakest link. We want to know if that is true. But I am more concerned about the decline in drama production on ABC television and, what is less noticed, the impact on ABC radio. The ABC radio drama on ABC-FM, Soundstage, which went for years and which was very successful, has now been undermined. Soundstage was on ABC-FM for 25 years and has now gone. We have had cuts to artists’ fees on ABC radio. I want to know where are the resources for drama production on TV and radio? In drama production I include documentary productionAustralian new material with Australian stories told by Australians to Australians. That is why we provide money to the ABC. It is why it is such a great icon in this country, because it is how we see and hear our own stories, things that do not appear anywhere else. It is being cut, hacked and pulled back. Since 1996 we have had substantial cuts to ABC funding, and this is a hole the government has not even filled in. The government is claiming great virtue in providing $17 million, which goes a very small part of the way to filling in the hole-and as best as we can tell none of that money is available for ABC drama production on TV and radio. Ostensibly it is available for any purpose but it appears that there are agreements between the government and the ABC that this money will be supplied for what seem to me to be very worthwhile purposes, of which I am not critical, but there seems to be nothing for drama production for TV and radio. The last point I have time to make is that the minister has claimed in his media release that the ABC in Perth has been financed to purchase and construct a new office. That is quite a good thing, but what he neglects to mention is that, in the move, the ABC has sold the purpose-built home for the West Australian Symphony Orchestra and provided no new home. So we have the West Australian Symphony Orchestra-one of the great orchestras of this country and very important for the most isolated capital city in the world-with the threat of no home, a state government trying to come up with ways to rescue that terrible situation, and silence from the federal government. We have a budget that is disastrous for the arts and artists and for Australians who love the arts, and that flies in the face of what a knowledge nation in the 21st century should require. the member for Fraser in his invaluable contribution to this debate, particularly regarding parallel imports in relation to the book industry, and his support for the ABC. The ABC is an important national institution and I am here this afternoon once again to support the ABC. Anyone who has any doubts about my credentials on this topic need look no further than the Hansard records of 21 June 1999, 9 August 1999, 22 November 1999, 31 October 2000 and 6 December 2000, when I participated in the MPI debate in respect of the funding cuts to the ABC and also questions on notice. I will get to that in a minute. My concern is that under this government over the last six years we have seen $66 million of cuts to the ABC budget. speaker: Mr Murphy (Lowe) (4.21 P.m.)
theText: I would like to begin by supporting the comments by28218 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 June 2001 $17.78 million per year. If you want any indication of the significance of that against the background of the significant funding cuts over the life of the last two parliaments under the Howard government, you have only to refer to this question which we all heard the Leader of the Opposition ask the Prime Minister today: Prime Minister, how can you justify spending $20 million a month on government advertising when you were only prepared to give the ABC an extra $17 million a year? Why is spending $20 million a month to save your political skin a higher priority than adequately funding the national broadcaster? This is further evidence of the dishonesty of the Howard government in terms of its attack on the ABC, that the best that it can offer is a restoration of $17 million a year when it is quite happy to spend $20 million of your money, Australian taxpayers’ money, to be re-elected. It is a very cynical exercise. What could be more important than maintenance of the national public broadcaster? Unfortunately, in Australia most of the public opinion is manipulated by the Murdoch group or the Packer group. I have expressed concern on many occasions about our media laws. If we continue to erode the funding to the ABC, as has occurred under this government, we are going to be left, particularly in this digital age, with more of Mr Packer and more of Mr Murdoch. Clearly, that is not in the public interest. The greatest threat to our democracy is concentration of the media. If we do not get a further opinion-that is, an opinion from the public broadcaster-God help this country. The criticism which is being levelled at the ABC at the moment-that it is biased and is presenting the views of, or running an agenda to support, the opposition-is not a fair criticism. You only have to look at the history of the ABC: the criticism was levelled at the ABC when we were in government, both in New South Wales under Premier Wran and more recently in federal government under Prime Minister Hawke and Prime Minister Keating. There was considerable criticism of the ABC from our side of politics. As I have said before in this chamber, if the ABC runs an editorial of the day which is against the interests of government, state or federal, people are going to cry that there is bias. We have to truly make the ABC independent and properly resourced. We have to fund the ABC. I have a clear recollection of Minister Alston prior to the last federal election promising that he would preserve the funding and independence of the ABC. What have we seen of the behaviour of Minister Alston? More recently we had that fiasco in the Senate estimates hearing where he did not like the very rigorous scrutiny that was being visited by the committee on Managing Director Shier in terms of his accountability to the taxpayers of Australia for his management of the ABC. He attempted to shut down that committee. Senator Alston could not cop the heat and attempted to hijack that committee or even usurp the role of the chairman of that committee. That clearly shows the duplicity of Senator Alston because he promised to maintain funding and independence, and he attempted to shut down the committee. One thing I have a real concern about in terms of the funding relates to a question that I put on notice to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts on 2 November 2000. I asked the minister: Will the Minister allow the Australian Broadcasting Corporation to become a fully-fledged business in e-commerce, deriving advertising revenue from its web sites or associated web sites? What do you think his response was? He said: The ABC is an independent statutory corporation established under the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983. The Government has no role in programming or operational matters. Section 25 of the Act empowers the ABC to enter into contracts, acquire and dispose of property and do other things incidental to its powers. It is the responsibility of the ABC Board to ensure that any activities undertaken by the ABC, including any online activities, are consistent with the Act and do not in any way affect the ABC’s editorial independence. What we have here in writing, enshrined in Hansard on 28 November 2000, is the minister’s acquiescence with regard to the ABC being able to raise revenue to obviously plug the hole from the very savage budget cuts that the Howard government has visited on the ABC. This is a very serious issue because I believe that the ABC should have a finite budget which is given to them at the start of the financial year so they know exactly what money they have to manage their full operations. In recent times, we have seen a serious decline in localism in both commercial radio and commercial television in regional areas. As one with a long background in regional radio and television, I feel more than competent to speak on it. What we have in many cases is a monopolisation of the market by similar interests-and I refer here particularly to the Daily Mail group-and a reduction of local content to bare, minimal proportions. In television, the demise of Prime Television news services in three major centres after years of cutbacks and the forcing of generic material onto others has so diluted localism in all markets as to make an absolute joke of the reasons for the Labor government’s aggregation policies of the late 1980s. theText: While I sympathise with many of the comments fromWednesday, 20 June 2001 MAIN COMMITTEE 28221 vertising market to absentee owners and to sacrifice local employment and content for halfhour strip network programming. MightI say, along with this, we see the demise of quality training of young journalists, broadcasters and announcers who once were the source of talent for the city stations. They are not taking on their responsibilities for training people. They are relying on the Charles Sturts of this world to train their young journalists, who in turn have fewer and fewer opportunities to do their work experience at the regional stations where their training was honed, if you like. WIN Television and the other Nine Network affiliates are the only operators consistently providing local news services to all their markets. However, even that is a long way short of the varied news, sport and entertainment that localism once provided under the licence requirements in the former incumbent regional station markets. (Extension of time granted) I remember preparing details for licence renewal hearings that would require a listing of towns and shires, and the number of stories, the number of information programs and so on that you had provided for all of those. It was a very worthwhile exercise-time consuming, but one that constantly reminded the licensee of his or her responsibility to that market. That sort of thing does not occur any more, and I ask: why? Members of the former government may want to promote the virtues of aggregation and say that this government is now standing mutely by while TV and radio services are delocalised, but there was never any intention to do other than maximise returns from licence sales and let the media operators do as they wish. The Ten Network affiliates were at least quite honest about what they regarded aggregation as-simply a licence to print money, with nothing by way of localism returned. They have never provided a news service in anything other than their incumbent market. The taxpayer should be informed that the Prime Network alone received $32 million of public funds to help it gear up for aggregation and will receive a $56 million subsidy, as far as I can ascertain, to ease it into the digital world. Also, it can ride on the back of the Seven Network’s signal in those markets where it was not the incumbent. The Ten Network affiliates in similar circumstances have taken similar public funding and run, with no regulatory framework to insist on localism. What we need, but no government is inclined to take on the media owners, are regulations requiring adequate and comprehensive localism from each licensee in each market; not contributing to but providing localism-and that is the key point. Anything else, any other inquiry recommendation from the radio inquiry now under way, would be, to use the Prime Minister’s current favourite term, pure humbug. I want to move quickly on to Telstra and rural communications. I opened the Telstra Countrywide office last week in Orange. While it is good to have people on the ground who can listen to the problems and see the frustration and delays in connections and repairs, it is but a reincarnation of Telecom local offices, minus the corporate knowledge of that network. That is what they are lacking, Minister: the corporate knowledge. If you pick up the phone and ring Gavin Priestley, the manager in Orange, and have a chat to him, I think he would quite frankly admit that they came in there not knowing the extent of the network or how many repairs they had. They had contractors coming in to dig the trench and they found that they did not have enough capacity on the line. That is in suburbs of Bathurst; it is not at Tibooburra. Gavin Priestley knows the extent of the problem now but he does not have the resources to do the job. Local subcontractors are being kept on a drip, fed by major contractors such as Lucas and Thiess, who are giving them unsustainable rates. Telstra continues to be top heavy and is only just beginning to come to grips with the work needed to bring rural telecommunications up to speed. That includes areas within 25 kilometres of the Bathurst Post Office. 28222 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 June 2001 Ms HOARE (Charlton) (4.43 p.m.)-In the short time available to me to address the issues within this portfolio, I would like to talk about Telstra, and emphasise the fact that the budget still includes the proceeds from the sale of Telstra in aggregate form in the headline cash balance from 2002-03. Previously the proceeds were included from 2000-01. Estimated proceeds from the sale have never been disclosed in any detail. Although still unsatisfactory, Budget Paper No. 1 does provide some information about the estimated net impact of revisions since the mid-year economic forecasts on the fiscal and underlying cash balances. The bottom line is that the government is trying to have its cake and eat it too. On the one hand it says that Telstra will only be sold after satisfactory implementation of the Besley measures, but on the other hand it is keen to keep it in the budget, potentially to use the estimated proceeds in the election campaign. Back in July 1999 Brian Toohey writing in the Sydney Morning Herald forecast this when he said: With the telecommunications giant valued on the sharemarket at more than $110 billion, Telstra could easily be capitalised at well over $120 billion by the time the next election is due in 2001. Brian Toohey on that occasion had it right. Two years down the track, that is exactly what this government is doing. This is a double standard and, should this mean and tricky government be re-elected, it surely will push ahead with the sale of Telstra. I am sure members will be aware that in recent days Telstra announced planned changes to its local call zones. It is astonishing that the minister, Senator Alston, has claimed credit on behalf of the government for Telstra’s response to Telstra’s own call zone review. Surely, any benefit that this government can claim for Telstra’s response can only have come about because of the government’s majority ownership of Telstra, and remember that, in the unfortunate circumstance that the government is returned at the next federal election and it goes through with the full privatisation of Telstra, this ability to encourage or influence Telstra to improve its services to the people of Australia will be lost. Senator Alston has also claimed that it would be a recipe for disaster for a majority government owned Telstra to play a nation building role as advocated by the Leader of the Opposition. Again, it is interesting to note that the minister advocated such a role for Telstra recently. He said the government certainly sees telcos as having a crucial role to play in nation building. What extraordinary hypocrisy from the minister. However, there is another example that I would like to raise of this government’s attitude to the government ownership of Telstra. Recently, Cable and Wireless announced the sale of Optus to SingTel, a company with majority ownership by the Singaporean government. It seems that it is all right for a telco to be owned by a government as long as it is not the Australian government. SingTel and Telstra are both excellent examples amongst others around the world of very effective telecommunications carriers partially owned by the public. In March this year, we saw the dividend that has been paid to the government by Telstra. When Telstra cemented its position as Australia’s biggest earning company, reporting a record $2.6 billion after-tax profit for the six months to December 2000, a $500 million dividend cheque went to the government as Telstra’s 50.1 per cent majority owner. But at that stage, the Prime Minister backed away from full privatisation saying that the government would not sell its stake until services in the bush were fixed, and in March he said, ‘I am not satisfied at present.’ However, in May it is there in the budget papers. The Prime Minister, if he is re-elected, will sell Telstra at any cost. Despite this government’s blatant and shameless hypocrisy, the full privatisation of Telstra will be a reality in the final year of the next parliament, should the Howard government be reWednesday, 20 June 2001 MAIN COMMITTEE 28223 elected. The government had decided to put the sensitive issue of privatisation on the backburner, but the public remains committed and the Labor Party remains committed to the preservation of the remainder of Telstra under public control as the only guarantee of quality service. theText: Through you, Mr Deputy Speaker: he does not know what he is talkingWednesday, 20 June 2001 MAIN COMMITTEE 28225 I have in mind a particular circumstance, the community of Kaltukatjarra, in the southwestern corner of the Northern Territory. They have been informed recently by Ngaanyatjarra Air, who have been providing them with Australia Post services twice a week, that they will no longer be provided with an air service. As a consequence, at the end of June they will no longer have access to mail. I hope the minister is listening, because potentially we are seeing, at the end of next week, a remote community in the Northern Territory no longer getting access to their mail by air. The difficulty we have here is that although RASS applies to the region there is no carrier. There is no carrier currently flying into this community. I would ask the minister to ascertain how we can ensure that this community will not, as of the end of June, be denied a mail service, the right of every Australian. We are talking about a community of some 300 or 400 people. In the past-and this goes over into another portfolio area-Ngaanyatjarra Air have supplied the service on the basis that they could carry passengers, and they carried those passengers and delivered mail to remote communities. What has happened subsequently is they have been denied the right to carry passengers on these services unless the planes become regular passenger planes on regular service schedules. They cannot do that because of the state of the airstrips. (Extension of time granted) This issue, which has been raised with the Department of Transport and Regional Services, is significant because not only will it affect Kaltukatjarra but it could affect other communities in the very near future. The bottom line is that we as a community have a responsibility to ensure that communities, wherever they might be, have access to a mail service. If there is no ability to fly the mail into this community some 900 kilometres south-west of Alice Springs, it seems to me incumbent on the government and Australia Post to ensure that the people there get their regular mail services in some way. I am happy to provide the minister with appropriate information about that if he requires it. In fact, I will write him a note and ensure he gets a copy of it tomorrow. I would like a response as soon as possible because, clearly, this community will be affected as of the end of next week. The other issue which I want to raise and which I have raised in this place on a number of occasions is in the area of telecommunications. I am a great supporter of Telstra and Telstra Countrywide. But I am not a great supporter of some of the decisions which have been made by the Telstra board, one of those decisions being to sell off its Commander phone system. You will recall, Mr Deputy Speaker, that I have raised this in the parliament before. What it meant was that, by selling off a portion of its business to a company of which it owned 30 per cent, it effectively privatised the business and started to charge people the full cost of providing a service. I will give you an example. The Ngadunggay Homelands Resource Centre was quoted a purchase price for a new Commander phone system of $2,582 plus an estimated $300 service fee for installation. Then there was to be a discount of $120 for the old equipment, and then travel costs for the installation, of $2,450. This has arisen because Telstra personnel can no longer put in place these services. This not only affects remote Aboriginal communities but also businesses in remote parts of Australia. PlesTel and PlesTel’s agents are only in Darwin and Katherine and Alice Springs in the Northern Territory. For the travel from Darwin or Katherine or Alice Springs to wherever the community might be, they are charging the travel time, the cost of the travel, plus the time on the job. Remember, these people previously had a contract with Telstra. Telstra put in place the systems. Now we are in a situation where these people are being penalised for the fact that Telstra has sold a part of its business. 28226 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 June 2001 I am advised, Mr Deputy Speaker, and through you to the minister, that it is possible that the PABX system may go the same way in the future. Of course, because I am talking to a minister who says he knows something about regional Australia, he would understand the import and the impact of selling off these little bits of Telstra bit by bit and then charging full costs to clients when these bits are sold off in such a way, and what it means in terms of the cost structure of small business and of community based organisations such as those that predominate in Aboriginal communities. The answer is pretty simple. Telstra has got to assert its right to ensure that its technicians are compelled to and can fix Commander phone systems, whether by licence or by agreement with PlesTel. They ought to do it as soon as possible. This is one of the very reasons why people in remote Australia will not tolerate the further sale of any bit of Telstra. WhatI say to the government and the minister, is that, if they believe that somehow or other the community believes it is advantaged by what they have done with Telstra and the fact that Telstra is now selling off little bits of itself to companies of which it is a part owner, I think they are sadly mistaken. The community is not being advantaged by it; it is being handicapped by it. To my way of thinking we ought to be contemplating what ‘universal service obligation’ properly means. I do not believe it means the right for Telstra to withdraw services and then compel people in these remote communities to pay full costs. Something must be done about it immediately. theText: Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation)Wednesday, 20 June 2001 MAIN COMMITTEE 28227 the moment, apart from the brief notification you have given, we know nothing about the issue. Ms Hall interjectingI asked the member for Perth the same question in the House this afternoon and he would not say. The bottom line on this-and just one phrase says it all-is that the coalition’s funding for the ABC is $96.5 million more than Labor’s last budget for the ABC. (Extension of time granted) Is there anybody on the opposition side who would like to contest that figure, that the coalition’s funding for the ABC is $96.5 million more than their last budget? The member for Shortland pleaded with the government not to interfere with the independence of the ABC. She believes the ABC should be equally critical of the government and the opposition. In fact, the ABC is more critical on this issue of independence of the Labor Party than it is of the coalition. I presented a statement by Brian Johns, the then chief executive officer, to the House in February of last year. The headline read ‘ALP attacks independence of the ABC’. He went on in the statement to criticise severely, in unambiguous terms, the member for Perth for threatening the independence of the ABC. The problem is that the ALP has form on this issue. Whether it is Greg Turnbull, press secretary to Kim Beazley, personally intimidating Mark Willesee of A Current Affair and warning him that the ALP will remember this in government or whether it is the ALP’s policy of tied grants to the ABC, it is the ALP threatening the national broadcaster’s independence. The problem with this whole ABC debate that has been generated by members of the ALP and the Friends of the ABC is that it is so much hype. It is exaggeration built upon generalisation. Tell us, member for Shortland, where there are examples of a coalition threat to the independence of the ABC. Give us some examples. At least do us the honour of telling us what actions of the government threaten the ABC’s independence. Ms Hall-Take a look at the board for a start, and its appointments.

With the help of the CPSU and the Friends of the ABC, you believe that they will. They remember Telecom and the PMG. What they want are legislative and regulated minimum service guarantees and the like. Don’t worry; if you think you can whip up a scare campaign simply by employing the rhetoric of fear, you are going to be sadly let down.

speaker: Mr Mcgauran
theText: Mr Deputy Speaker, I have just remembered one other phoney pieceWednesday, 20 June 2001 MAIN COMMITTEE 28229 The member for Charlton attacked the government for claiming any credit for the call zone benefits that Telstra announced over the weekend. So it is all the government’s fault when anything happens in communications, as evidenced by the attack by the member for the Northern Territory today in regard to Telstra. It is all our fault if there is some decrease in service, some failed connection, some delayed repair, but when they announce a major initiative that will benefit hundreds of thousands of country people, it has nothing to do with the government. You can’t have it both ways. Let me deal quickly with the comments by the member for Calare. He spoke at great length about aggregation. This was entirely predictable. I was part of those debates in the late 1980s. We pleaded with and begged the government of the day, ‘Don’t aggregate.’ They gave in to their big network mates. Make no mistake about this: anyone who was around at that time will tell you what was driving this policy, and I do not think it is talking out of school to say that the minister for communications at the time, Michael Duffy, was never very comfortable with the special deals that Hawke and Keating struck with the broadcasters at that time. We knew what aggregation would do to regional broadcasters, and it all happened within a matter of years. I do not know why the member for Calare, in the year 2001, 10 or 12 years after the event, expresses concern. We predicted this at the time; it happened very quickly. What is happening to Prime’s local TV service at the moment is very regrettable. He had a go at Countrywide. He is wrong on Countrywide, and I am happy to work to convince him otherwise. I have had Countrywide in my electorate for about six to eight months. It is the best thing that could have happened. Peter Ward heads the most dedicated people. They criss-cross the electorate; they visit people in their homes. It does not matter how remote you are, they will go to your doorstep and help you with connections or with mobile phone coverage. They are a great organisation. We have just announced the upgrade of 53 exchanges throughout Gippsland. I do not get many chances to speak about Golden Beach, which is a small community of about 300 people, but we launched the first upgrade of those 53 Gippsland exchanges there only last week. I implore the member for Calare to give Countrywide a chance. It is the real McCoy. With respect to the comments by the member for Lowe, we have heard all of this beforethe ABC’s independence, concentration of media by Packer and Murdoch. Well, fine, but the trouble is there is only so much breast beating allowable before it gets very repetitious and you devalue the currency. I should really have dealt longer with the remarks by the member for Fraser, because he is the shadow minister for the arts. But the problem is that I have heard it all before. It was a very unoriginal contribution. Of course, money was not mentioned; he just listed the problem areas while providing no solutions in policy terms, let alone in funding terms. You are not going to get away with this. You try to be all things to all people; you promise the world and there is never a dollar figure attached to it. As the Treasurer said not long ago, he is going to remind opposition members of this day in and day out. In that he will be aided by each and every one of his colleagues. The member for Fraser spent some time on the book industry and parallel imports. He has once again allied himself to special interests, against the interests of consumers. Parallel importing of books is in the interest of consumers; parallel importing of CDs was also in the interest of consumers. We were told the world would collapse; it has not. Quite frankly, the member for Fraser is just a mouthpiece for special interests against the interests of the broader community. Apart from that, I thank the member for Calare for his contribution. Proposed expenditure agreed to. 28230 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 June 2001 Department of Family and Community Services Proposed expenditure, $2,833,202,000. budget was its failure to do anything for struggling Australian families. As we know, families provide the learning and caring environment for children that enhances their chances of success and our economic stability. But our families are under threat. First of all, I think they have been hit for six by the GST. Under the government’s GST, families are paying more for the necessities of life-things like children’s clothes and electricity. They are also paying more for many other goods. The ABS consumer price index shows electricity is up 12 per cent, gas is up 10.4 per cent, insurance is up 35 per cent, telephone bills are up seven per cent, whitegoods are up 5.8 per cent, medicines are up six per cent, sporting fees are up 12.2 per cent, children’s shoes are up 7.3 per cent, kids’ glasses are up 6.4 per cent, bread is up four per cent, kids’ haircuts are up 11.7 per cent, petrol is up 7.8 per cent, books are up 9.2 per cent and education is up 4.5 per cent. The budget ignores these pressures on families that arise squarely from the imposition of the GST, and the government did not take the opportunity to address the looming family payments crisis that will see debts raised against low income families from July. This appropriation bill contains no item that will address the very real problems that lie at the heart of the government’s family payments system. The government claims that it is family friendly because it will index family payments on 1 July, but in a mean clawback the government is going to recoup much of this amount by hitting struggling families with many family payment debts that will come out of their tax returns. As always, what John Howard gives with one hand he takes away with the other. Families whose income has changed during this financial year face debts at tax time of up to $1,000 because of the legislation introduced with the GST. There are three family payments that are affected by the government’s new system which was supposed to be simple and fair: family tax benefit part A, family tax benefit part B and child-care benefit. The appropriation for these three payments will total approximately $11.5 billion in the coming financial year, so it is important that the money is fairly administered but it is not. For each of the three family payments, families have been asked to estimate their income a year in advance. These are the only government payments that operate on a yearly estimate made in advance. Because the government’s new system is a zero tolerance one, every dollar they underestimate their income by will produce a debt, as compared to the previous system where a 10 per cent tolerance was allowed. The government now has a zero tolerance family policy, which is going to be very tough on many low income Australian families, and if a family contacts Centrelink to revise their estimate of income during the year, this will not necessarily prevent them from incurring a debt after 1 July this year. To give you the size of the potential problem, you need to look at how many families are getting these payments and how many have changing income over the financial year. There are 1.8 million Australian families getting family tax benefit A, while 1.2 million families get family tax benefit B and 500,000 families receive child-care benefit. Senator Vanstone’s department has said that up to May 833,000 families had registered income changes during the present financial year, and so many of these people do not yet know that after July they will face a hefty bill from the government. You can safely assume from the department’s advice that some of these 833,000 may have changed their estimates more than once. Families in which there is a shift worker or someone working casually are likely to have a great many fluctuations in their income over the course of a year-something the government’s payment rules try to ignore.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Swan (Lilley) (5.19 P.m.)
theText: The gaping hole in the middle of the government’s recentWednesday, 20 June 2001 MAIN COMMITTEE 28231 The trouble is that the government will not come clean on how big the problem could be. The department has admitted in estimates hearings that around 200,000 of the 500,000 childcare benefit payments may produce debts, but they are unable to tell us how many of the three million FTB A and FTB B payments will produce debts for customers at tax time. They guess it is less than 40 per cent, but they are not sure. So all we know is that they expect less than 1.2 million payments to be affected. If history is any guide, the problem is big. The minister’s own departmental annual report records that there were 51,000 debts raised against families in 1999-2000, an average of $955 per family, and that was before the government’s zero tolerance family policy was introduced. The government could have addressed the problems at the core of its zero tolerance approach in the budget, but it did nothing and actively chose to do so. Instead, Centrelink officers, at the direction of the government, are telling families who come in to change their income estimate to falsely overestimate their income to try and make a dent in the debt that they are going to get at tax time. It is just another tricky approach for the government to avoid its responsibilities. (Extension of time granted) In some cases, they are telling them to cancel their payments so they can avoid a debt at the end of the year. Put simply, the government is encouraging families to mislead to save its own political hide, and they have to sign the form to cement the government’s deception. It is quite a unique situation. You have Minister Anthony only a few weeks ago crowing about Centrelink fraud detection figures, which include families who innocently incur family payment debts. It is not just Minister Anthony. The government has been very tricky and sneaky all along when it comes to family payments. Senator Vanstone insinuated in April that only families rorting the system would receive debts because of massively underestimating their income. She falsely claimed that a family would have to underestimate their income by $18,000 to receive a debt of $1,000. However, a yearly income estimate from a family could be out by as little as $1,500 to incur a $1,000 debt for one child. For a family earning $30,000, this amounts to an error of just five per cent. For the government, being 95 per cent just is not good enough. That is a direct result of its zero tolerance family policy. Debts accrue against each payment the family receives, not just the child-care benefit. Either the minister is not across the detail of her portfolio or she was being deliberately misleading when she made those statements. So you have ministers out there trying to paint the families who are innocently caught up in this system as fraudsters to ease the political pressure from the debts that they have created through their new system, and you have Centrelink, on instruction from the government, telling families to falsely estimate their income. The problem is that, for too many families, the government’s family payment system is very unfair. It is a dog and it bites. Olaf Meier, from Crestmead in Brisbane, has had his income increased from $32,700 to $35,950. He is facing a debt of around $700. He and his family are doing it pretty tough. They have just bought their home and they cannot afford not to be receiving family payments through the year. But now they face a debt approaching $1,000, courtesy of the Howard government’s zero tolerance family payment rules, and there are tens of thousands of families like the Meier family. These families cannot afford to provide an overestimate of their income, as Centrelink is directing, because they just cannot make ends meet day to day, week to week. These families, the ones who are doing it toughest, are at the top of the list to get $1,000 or more in debts in July or August this year. Many more families do not know about the debt problem, and they are going to find out for the first time what they owe when the tax office comes back to them with a bill instead of a cheque in July and August. Families receiving family tax benefit B, a payment to help a dependent spouse caring for a child, are also a real problem. It is this payment that produces the debt for families when a 28232 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 June 2001 spouse moves into the work force during the financial year. Just today, Professor Peter Macdonald has come out in a Monash University journal to explain the consequences of this payment on the lives of Australian families and the implications for Australia’s birthrate. Peter Macdonald’s work makes very clear why the government should have done something about the family payment system in the budget. He explains how the family tax benefit B payment penalises dual income families, which many young families are these days, forcing one parent to remain at home. Macdonald points to the case of a couple with a young child where the husband is earning $45,000 and the wife wants to return to work for 12 hours a week to help with the extras. From the $204 she would earn each week, the wife would lose $16 in tax, $20 in transport costs, $30 in child-care costs and $50 in family tax benefit B. Put simply, she would be working for $88 a week. If, however, her husband takes on an extra 12 hours a week, the family gains $225 a week in extra income. According to Macdonald, this means the payment rewards families where the husband absents himself more and more from his family. How perverse can you get. Our Prime Minister’s world and the world of Minister Anthony and Minister Vanstone is the world of the 1950s, where wives may have stayed at home while fathers worked nine to five and had constant incomes. But the rest of us, Minister, are living in the 21st century, where Australian families are trying to survive with intermittent overtime, casual work and a 10 per cent GST. So despite all of the admissions by the minister’s department in estimates hearings and all of the families coming forward with evidence that they are about to be saddled with debts, the government continues to pretend that anyone getting a debt is some kind of cheat, and that is deeply insulting to these hard working Australians. Just a week ago, Senator Vanstone claimed the government was very family friendly. She put out this statement saying ‘Family friendly government’. (Extension of time granted) She claimed that her system of family payments ‘is a fair and equitable policy that will enable families to receive what is rightly theirs’. She said that it reflects the Howard government’s commitment to pay people what they are entitled to-no more, no less. Once again, there is the clear implication that people who receive debts are doing it deliberately. Once again, there is the smear that these people may be defrauding the system and are not victims of this government’s system. The fact is that this minister is determined to prop up an unfair zero tolerance family payments system by blaming the struggling families who fall victim to it. The fact is that Australian families do not have crystal balls to predict their future income and most do not have the accounting software to deal with the government’s complicated zero tolerance family payments policy. John Howard is not supporting battling Australian families; he is out there creating more of them. Tens of thousands of families are being put under extreme financial pressure. Only someone as out of touch and cold-hearted as our Prime Minister and his ministers would introduce a family payments system that punishes families who work harder and punishes parents who return to work after taking time out to care for a child. John Howard’s zero tolerance family payments system is just another mean GST compensation swindle. John Howard’s zero tolerance family payments policy sits proudly alongside his other achievements-the bogus savings bonus and pension clawback-in the coalition’s GST compensation hall of shame. Ms HALL (Shortland) (5.31 p.m.)-This is a high taxing government, a government that has delivered a tax to the Australian people that is really affecting their lives. It is taxing families in a way that they have never been taxed before. I visited one of the schools in my electorate last week. When I arrived at that school the students asked me about the GST. When they asked me about the GST they identified the fact that they had started paying tax. They also identified their feeling that this was not the way it should be; rather, that you should Wednesday, 20 June 2001 MAIN COMMITTEE 28233 start to pay tax when you started work. They felt it was very unfair that they were being hit in this way. Probably the greatest disappointment to me in this budget was the fact that the government failed to acknowledge that they had dudded people who live in residential parks and caravan parks. They continue to impose this 5½ per cent GST on these very vulnerable people who are generally on fixed incomes. The Minister for Community Services, who is present in the chamber, knows about this, because he, like me, has a lot of residents who live in these parks. These people have made the decision to have this lifestyle. They are people who own their own homes. They are people who have invested significant amounts of money-some nearly as much as $200,000-in buying their homes. It was really brought home to me last weekend when I was talking to residents who were living in parks how hard it is for them. When the GST was introduced, a number of owners of parks imposed a rental increase; others imposed the GST. Now we are finding an about-face by some of those owners who applied the GST because they can see the writing on the wall. They see that the government may lose the next election, and if they lose the next election they know that the Labor Party has promised that the GST, that unfair GST that has been charged on people who are living in residential parks, will be removed. Because of that, I am finding that within the area that I represent park owners are sending letters to the residents saying, ‘We’ve decided the GST’s not the way to go, we’re going to put in place a rent increase.’ I think that the government should have admitted that it made a mistake. In admitting that it made a mistake, it should then, in this budget, have remedied that situation. (Extension of time granted) It has already rolled back the GST on excise. It has already had to introduce rollback in a number of areas-or, should I say, as I think it is more appropriate when I am referring to the government, rollover, because it is only when they have the pressure put on them through the polls and the ballot box that they actually revisit any of these issues. The minister should be very aware of this because of the electorate he represents. I would have thought that he would have been leading the fight for the residents of these parks because it will have an impact in his electorate. Even putting that aside, I think that on moral grounds he should be fighting for these people. I honestly do not see how members on that side of the House can live with the fact that the government is spending $20 million a month on advertising whilst, at the same time, it is hitting the most vulnerable people within our community with taxes like the GST on people in parks. The shadow minister spoke about the debts that are being levied against families. I have already seen some of those families-they are coming into my electorate office. The zero tolerance on debts incurred on the family benefits A and B is hurting families and will continue to hurt families. This matter needs to be revisited, Minister. You need to re-introduce the 10 per cent leeway. Because of the way this government has attacked the job market, more and more people are working in part-time and casual jobs and being forced to work long hours, and that does have an enormous effect on their incomes. It is very difficult to estimate how much you are going to earn when the hours you work vary from week to week. This is not a family friendly government. It is a government that uses all the rhetoric. It says, ‘We care about families. We are there for the family. We support family values,’ but it is nothing more than rhetoric. What it does support is being re-elected. What it does support is an outmoded picture of what it thinks Australia is and should be, and then goes about trying to achieve it by hitting the people that it is supposed to be supporting. I feel that the government has failed miserably in the area of family and community services. It has not looked after the 28234 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 June 2001 people. It has not provided the support for the people in our community that are most vulnerable. The other area I should quickly touch on is the number of breaches that are being imposed by Centrelink. The simple fact that a large percentage of these breaches are administrative has been borne out by some of the answers that the minister has provided me with to questions in relation to the Shortland electorate and the people who have been breached there. Every day we have people coming into our electorate office who have been unfairly breached. It takes time, both within our office and within Centrelink, to actually turn around decisions that have been made by Centrelink. I think that the minister would do well to provide extra staff and extra training to Centrelink. Probably if he could give a little bit more support in that area it would be appreciated, not only by the staff at Centrelink but by the people that rely on Centrelink for their payments. pressed by some of my colleagues about the very great problems that are being caused to Australian families as a result of overpayments of family payment. I would like to raise a particular area of that collection procedure and that is the interrelationship between it and the Child Support Agency. This is a matter that I have already written about to Senator Vanstone and to the Treasurer and I will briefly outline the problem for the benefit of other members. The person who brought this to my attention had custody of her two children for most of the year. She had been claiming a full family tax benefit. Relatively late in the year, the residential arrangements for one of the children changed, so that that child then resided with his father, giving his father an entitlement to part of the family tax benefit for those two children for the year. That father had a child support debt to the mother of many thousands of dollars. Her concern was that her ex-husband would claim his share of the family tax benefit through Centrelink, and a debt would be raised against her, and Centrelink would not take that money and apply it against his child support debt. She had correctly assessed the situation, as I have subsequently found out from my own inquiries. thing is that, as the minister has just said, presently there is no legislative arrangement that links the Child Support Agency with Centrelink as far as debt collection goes. I then explored the issue of what would happen if the father claimed the money in his tax return. I thought, ‘There are links between the ATO and the Child Support Agency in relation to the resolution of child support debts.’ However, I found that the administrative arrangements are not as I would have expected. The father could put in his claim but, because the mother had claimed a full family tax benefit, the claim would be rejected. At that point, his income tax assessment would be issued. If, for other reasons, he had a repayment due to him of any tax, that would be applied against the Child Support Agency debt. However, in a lot of these cases fathers are in circumstances where they are not necessarily going to receive a refund and, therefore, the child support debt is not going to be dealt with at all. The next step is that the father has to apply for a review, so that he can get access to his share of the family tax benefit. When he does that and it is processed, a debt will be raised against the mother and the money will be paid to the father. At that point, there is no link between the tax office and the Child Support Agency for the purposes of clearing child support debts. So, the mother who is owed several thousand dollars by the father continues to be owed several thousand dollars by the father. He receives part of the family tax benefit-that is paid to him in his hand-and she has a debt raised against her. I think that is an extremely inequitable situation, and if the minister, as he has said, has some legislation coming forward that
