theText: I hope you have got some legislation going through to solve the problem. TheWednesday, 20 June 2001 MAIN COMMITTEE 28235 will resolve the problem in relation to overpayments claimed through Centrelink, that is great. ThenI would hope that he would also follow up the issue of the payment system with the tax office. (Time expired) debate, so it may be a little fragmented. However, I would suggest that the reaction out there after the budget is one of some cynicism even among those who have enjoyed some of the rewards of that budget. I think the general feeling is that, stung by the impact of the goods and services tax on pensioners, the government has moved to placate that sector with a targeted election year handout. I think that, if governments continue to use that sort of tactic, more and more people will gravitate to that 20-30 per cent of the population who are looking for candidates other than those from the major parties to represent them. You just cannot sit back and say, ‘Those preferences will drift back to us anyway so we do not have to worry about it.’ I think the political system has to worry very sincerely about the fact that there is a disillusioned 20 to 30 per cent out there who, I believe, will only be reinforced because of a repetition of a variation of the whiteboard hand-out mentality, if you like. I said on budget night that the one-off $300 handout for each person receiving a pension or part-pension looked like a blatant election bribe, and everything I have seen or heard since confirms that analysis. Those who got it can perhaps pay off their winter fuel bill-or part of it-in my electorate, where four per cent, with a sunset clause, compensation for the GST in the first place was never going to be enough, particularly in a rural cold winter electorate where fuel prices for heating, although not the government’s fault, have indeed gone through the roof. The costs have risen significantly post GST-some of it no doubt unexpected with those skyrocketing fuel prices-but just like the fine print had to be read with the famous promise of that $1,000 bonus to pensioners to compensate for the GST, so too the fine print had to be read with this budget bonus. Many missed out on the $1,000 and many have missed out on this. Disability support pensioners and non-pensioner carers or non-pension age carers also feeling the post-GST price hikes have angrily contacted my office to ask why they did not receive this payment. One constituent says: The recent announcement of a one-off payment to pensioners of $300 is (like the $1,000 GST bonus promise) again misleading and hurtful to many gullible enough to take the leader of the Australian people at his word. I am unaware of the ratio of aged pensioners to the sum of all other categories of pensioners, but that figure would closely reflect the number of vulnerable Australians hurt and disillusioned by the continued misrepresentation of the truth. He goes on: I am a disability support pensioner. ThatI can recognise the existence of the ambiguity/deception inherent in the continued misuse of the term ‘pensioner’ when it is intended not to apply to all pensioners, should at least call into question the candour of those so cavalier with its use. These words, among others, are from Paul Collins in my electorate. If there is one thing clear to me after six budgets in this place, it is the fact that all too often measures announced as black and white with such conviction on budget night, and reported as such the day after quite uncritically by the media, turn out to be ambiguous or deceptive on further analysis. As another example, self-funded retirees could have been forgiven for thinking after budget night that they would all benefit equally from the government’s proposed changes to the low income rebate system. But that was not the case, with income cut-offs meaning many self-funded retirees will receive no benefit whatsoever. In the same way as the much heralded scheme to allow farmers to pass on their property to their family failed to live up to its promise to enable 10,000 farmers to access the pensionand it would have if that rate had been of $800,000 value instead of half a million, but it deliv-

speaker: Mr Andren (Calare) (5.44 P.m.)
theText: This is part of a speech I had prepared for the main28236 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 June 2001 ered for only 2,000-so, again, measures promoted as helping many will only aid the few. That real or perceived deceit is undoing much of the positive reaction the government might hope to gain from these initiatives and any amount of advertising will not turn this around. express concern for an organisation which has not been guaranteed funding in this budgetthat is, the Women’s Emergency Services Network. Today, I met with people from WESNET, the peak women’s organisation working to eliminate domestic and family violence. Some three years ago this organisation had its funding threatened. A lot of other peak organisations-such as AYPAC, in terms of the youth sector, Shelter in terms of social housing and the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation-have had their funding withdrawn by this government. WESNET’s funding runs out on 30 June and it needs the support of the government. I call upon the government and the minister to give it its funding, which is pretty minimal. The organisation has, for the last three years, been getting $110,000 per year. speaker: Mr Anthony (Richmond
theText: Minister for Community Services) (5.54 p.m.)-I know thatWednesday, 20 June 2001 MAIN COMMITTEE 28237 has had, particularly on families, and of course he was being very indignant about the dramatic increase in assistance that we have given, particularly to families, through the new taxation system. Part of that has been the substantial increases in family tax benefit. There was $2.2 billion of new money that came through after 1 July this year to compensate families for any possible price increase that might have come about due to the new taxation system$2.2 billion. For low income families, particularly for some of those receiving family tax benefit, that was an increase in the order of $40 to $50 per week in family tax benefit. We also increased family tax benefit part B. This was done to give families choice when one of the primary carers might not wish to enter the work force, and assistance is now given to those individuals. We do believe in choice, which is fundamentally important in the new taxation system. We have given them a substantial increase in funding through the family tax benefit, but there are also benefits to families, particularly through reductions in income tax rates, which are also substantial. But the best thing that this coalition government has done to assist families has been our stewardship over the last five years in ensuring that there has been a reduction in interest rates. These major reductions in interest rates-which are now at their lowest levels for decades-have meant that the cost of living is far more manageable for families, particularly mortgages. When Labor was at its zenith, particularly when the Leader of the Opposition was minister for finance, interest rates for home mortgages were at 17 per cent. So this has been a very family friendly budget, and these measures are certainly profamily. He also commented on the issue of reconciliation. Yes, we do have a policy to ensure that families get their estimates accurately. That is why we have now put on a lot more staff at Centrelink-to ensure that, if their circumstances do change, families can make contact either through their customer service centre or through the call centre to ensure that the estimates they get are correct. Under the old system, the Labor Party had 12 different types of payment for families-very complex and very confusing. We simplified that from 12 to three: family tax benefit part A, family tax benefit part B and child-care benefit-in which there has been a substantial increase. If we talk about child care, the last ABS statistics show that there has been a 10 per cent fall in the cost of child care. This has made it far more affordable than it ever was under the Australian Labor Party. Under reconciliation, for the first time if families underestimate their income-and they did not have this under the Labor Party-they will receive a top-up of up to 10 per cent. But we are conscious of the need for families to have their reconciliation accurate. That is why, through all the campaigns that we have run over the last couple of years, families are being educated about such things. Because they are receiving a lot more in taxpayers’ money through family tax benefit, we must ensure that their reconciliations and their estimates are correct. There are 2.2 million Australians who are receiving family tax benefit. Of those, 1.2 billion will receive family tax benefit part B, which is up to $108 per fortnight-and that is substantial. Regarding the comments made about fraud and detection figures, it is certainly this government that wants to ensure that taxpayers get their correct entitlement-not more, not less. We certainly will not tolerate individuals who deliberately go out of their way-not through wrong estimates-to try and defraud the Commonwealth and other taxpayers. (Extension of time granted) That is precisely why-because we have spent $56 billion in this budget-we have to ensure that taxpayers’ money is used accurately and appropriately. We do not step away from that, in contrast with the ramshackle days when the Department of Social Security was administered by the previous Labor government, where there was very little accountability. 28238 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 June 2001 The member for Lilley also spoke about an article by a leading academic that appeared in the paper today-again, an article about family tax benefit. As I mentioned before, what I believe has failed to be acknowledged is that family tax benefit, particularly part B, is there to give families choice. It is there to give families an option in the event that both parents want to return to the work force or perhaps one parent wishes to stay at home, particularly when their child is young. And yes, we have weighted it. If one partner wishes to stay at home and look after their child who is under the age of five, then there is a substantial increase. But, of course, if that particular partner returns to the work force, there is a reduction there. I believe that is very family friendly, and I disagree with some of the content of Peter Macdonald’s article in the paper today. Talking about the savings bonus, it was this government that, for the first time, compensated older Australians for a reduction in purchasing power through the introduction of the new taxation system-and that was never ever done when the Australian Labor Party were in government, particularly with their constant increases in wholesale sales taxes. These were hidden taxes that continued to go up: from 10 to 12, from 20 to 22. On it went, a plethora of hidden taxes, with there being absolutely no compensation being given to any Australians. What did we do? We were quite deliberate, when the new taxation system came into place, in stating that if you had a certain amount of savings, if you had been thrifty-particularly an older Australian-you would be entitled to a saving bonus. AndI might add that the average payment for the savings bonus is around $743 and, from memory, that went to about 1.8 million Australians. That was substantial. There was also recognition given to self-funded retirees through the supplementary bonus, and that was payable up to $2,000. The previous government never gave any compensation for any of its failed tax policies and its broken promises with income tax cuts that occurred in 1983-84. Mr Griffin interjectingsale sales taxes were introduced? Absolutely not. The member for Shortland, as well meaning as perhaps she is, comes in here preaching virtues; she says that there has been a lack of attention to the job market. Why is it then that we have created 840,000 new jobs since our stewardship here? There have been more jobs created now. There is lower unemployment; it is now under seven per cent, and it was well over 11 per cent when the Leader of the Opposition was minister for employment. She talks about breaches. At least we have a gradual regime in place for Centrelink-it was never there under the Department of Social Security, which was administered by the Australian Labor Party. They had a one-breach policy: you got breached and you lost your total entitlement. Again, from memory, there were about 80,000 breaches in Labor’s last full year, with people losing their total entitlement. What we did was to introduce a gradual system whereby you had a number of warnings before you lost your total entitlement. That was part of a recommendation that came to us from ACOSS and other welfare groups because of the draconian types of policies that existed in that area before. As far as Centrelink is concerned, a comment was made about extra staff. We are putting on extra staff. There will be substantially more staff going on under Australians Working Together, which is the core package of this appropriation bill. This is a very good thing, because we are starting to tackle some of those individuals who have been left behind-mature age workers, long-term unemployed, and particularly those people who are on disability support. The area that the member for Kingston spoke about, which I thought was a constructive contribution-unlike some of the others-was the interrelationship between the Child Support Agency and the new family tax benefit scheme. I think he was perhaps also referring to elements of shared care. We do have amendments to legislation now-(Time expired)

If those guidelines were good enough for Labor in 1993, I have no reason to find them suspect in 2001. They are good guidelines. They require honest responses. They require there to be a demonstrated need for the advertising. They require research to prove that this advertising is required. It needs to be budgeted, done properly and not be party political. The Australian Labor Party can crawl all they like and try to make cheap political points about government advertising. But there is a need to clearly explain to the community new services and new processes, not to deceive the public but to make sure they understand what their rights and their entitlements are, and what government programs have changed so that they know how their lives are going to change as a result. I wanted to put that on the record. We have had enough of this hypocrisy from the other side of parliament on this issue. Let us get down and debate substantive issues, in this case about the budget for the Department of Family and Community Services.

speaker: Mr Griffin (Bruce) (6.23 P.m.)
theText: I will speak briefly regarding a matter that relates toWednesday, 20 June 2001 MAIN COMMITTEE 28243 that manufacturers received for pharmaceutical products in Australia under the PBS with those obtained in countries with similar and dissimilar arrangements. It was commissioned by the Commonwealth government and arose out of discussions with the pharmaceutical industry working group. There were seven comparison countries selected: the US, Canada, the UK, France, Spain, Sweden and New Zealand, with France, Spain, Sweden and New Zealand considered to be similar to Australia. The preliminary results show that manufacturer prices in Australia for the top 150 pharmaceuticals are much lower than those in the US, Canada, the UK and Sweden, but manufacturer prices in Australia are closer to those in France and about the same as prices in Spain and New Zealand. However, it also made some points about the types and classes of drugs within that. For example, prices paid by the Australian government for truly innovative drugs-new chemical entities-are similar and in some cases higher than in comparable countries. The greatest price discrepancy is in this area of me-too drugs-that is, newer drugs that are more expensive but have similar therapeutic outcomes to older and cheaper drugs, where Australia pays less than comparable countries. The highest prices paid for pharmaceuticals are in countries where there are no real government controls on pricing, such as the US, where prices are almost double that paid in Australia. I believe this shows that under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme companies are awarded for true innovation and that prices for drugs that show little benefit over existing medications reflect their real rather than marketing benefits. It also shows the sort of cost-effectiveness controls established under the Hawke Labor government in 1998, which ensured that the high prices paid by consumers in the US are not being afflicted on the Australian taxpayer. The report, I believe, proves once and for all that, if the government sticks to the PBS pricing process and stops interfering at the behest of industry, the industry will be rewarded for real innovation and Australians will be rewarded by having a manageable scheme that provides effective and safe medicines to all at affordable prices. Dr WOOLDRIDGE (Casey-Minister for Health and Aged Care) (6.26 p.m.)-The member for Kingston raised a serious concern. I will attempt to give him a serious reply. One of the difficult things about being minister for health is that, even for someone who might be medically qualified such as me, it is hard to form a view about technology. It is hard to form a view on highly technical matters. Similarly, the PBS, which I will come to in a second, is another highly technical matter. What you tend to do is take the view of experts. This is proper. You set up expert committees. You try and get a range of views and then you try and force an expert committee to come to a consensus and give you a view. There will always be another expert who has a different view. We have seen it recently with the listing of the pharmaceutical Zyban and a researcher in Sydney getting a lot of publicity for taking one point of view yet the balance of opinion on my expert committee was to the contrary. The whole MRI process has been debated at very great length. But I guess, given the way it played out and given the behaviour of some in the area, the capacity for me to do anything other than take expert advice is very limited. I set up an expert committee under Professor Blandford. At no time did I seek to influence the outcome of that committee’s deliberations. I asked them what their expert view would be on the further extension of this new technology. We have substantially increased it in the last five years, even if some of it was by accident rather than design. Off the top of my head, I think you are looking at around $3 million per machine. The demand is limitless, so the only way you can try and put some cost control on it is to put some controls around the supply. 28244 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 June 2001 South Australia has three machines. Had the expert committee said to me, ‘Every children’s hospital in Australia needs one of these,’ I would have done everything I could to have implemented that. But that is not what the expert advice was. Again, unfortunately, in health care you find professionals who will use the public or use a particularly compelling case to try and argue for their own personal benefit. I am sure every radiological department in Australia would like one of these, but they are not going to get it unless the Commonwealth is prepared to chip another $100 million or so into radiologists’ incomes. I am not sure that is the best use of public money. In the specific case of South Australia, there are three funded machines. I accept completely what the honourable member says, that it necessitates a trip from time to time from one hospital to another to get a funded scan. I think that is probably a lot cheaper than putting a whole lot of extra machines in. I am sorry to hear the story the honourable member tells about his constituent child dying of cancer. It is always open another time for another committee to come back. On the issue of the state hospitals, of course it is open to a state government at any point in time to put a machine into its own hospital. It does not need Commonwealth authority or approval. He may or may not be aware that the actual inquest into the young lad’s death is currently under way in Melbourne, and there has been a range of issues considered and covered in the media over the last couple of days about what has actually occurred. For example, although the minister’s expectationand I must admit it was also mine-was that the change in excise duty would in fact lead to a situation where the alcohol essences that we were talking about were largely withering and dying on the vine, there appears to be significant anecdotal evidence that they are still out there. Partially I think that is a situation of old stock still being sold. The action that was taken was not going to take that into account, and I understand that. There are also some issues being raised about the question of duty being avoided on imports rather than product produced in Australia. That appears to be a problem with Customs, which has also been raised recently and could partly explain why some of those sorts of essences are still available. I would certainly urge him to comment-and I may well make some public comment myself in the next few days-about the fact that the labelling issue perhaps needs to be looked at again. I have some concerns about the decision taken by the ministerial council in this area and I would ask him to acquaint himself with that, because ANZFA made some recommendations to the ministerial council, which, with some reason but probably not sufficient reason, adjusted that decision. There is also the question of whether further action should be taken to remove these products from state and territory locations all up. The minister, at the time. I raised that aspect of the issue, made the point that that is a state and territory power and responsibility. I raised the point at the time, though, that I believe there may well be, under the Trade Practices Act, a capacity to act federally. I am not saying necessarily that that is the most appropriate way to do things, but I do think that we probably ought to have another look at the incidence of this product. Obviously there is an inquest going on, so I think we also need to look at what comes out of that inquest. I do think that there are some issues there and I certainly offer our support to look at what might be done. I think we would both agree that these particular essences ought not to be available publicly, in my view not even in licensed premises. I made some inquiries at the time at some 10 or 15 stores in the area that I represent and spoke to people about it. Essentially what was said was that two types of people were getting it: people who appeared to be buying it for minors and people who were pretty much derros. For those reasons I think these essences should be banned. Ms HALL (Shortland) (6.38 p.m.)-Whilst the minister is here, I will raise one issue and then go on to some other issues that I want to raise. Maybe he could just take on board what I am saying and consider it a little later. In the area that I come from-the Central Coast, the southern part of Newcastle-there is a chronic doctor shortage. It is an area where there is quite an elderly population. In fact it is the 16th oldest area in Australia, according to the ABS figures taken at the last census. What is happening there is that elderly people are having to wait between seven and 14 days to get a routine appointment with their local GP, particularly in the Central Coast area of the electorate. Some submissions have been sent to the department, and they have been rejected without even being considered, because of the classification of the area. It is classified as a RAMA 1 area. Those submissions have been sponsored by the local council and by the GPs in the area. They have the support of the Central Coast urban division of general practice and of the local pharmacist. They have my support as well, of course, as well as that of the local state member. To refuse to look at a submission just because of a classification and to refuse to allow some overseas doctors into the area-which is what we are hoping will be allowed-is a restrictive method of assessment. Minister, if you could look into that, I would be grateful. I will now move on to the other part of my contribution. The other thing that is a problem in the area that I come from is the shortage of GPs who bulk-bill. I was really disappointed that there was no move in the budget to encourage GPs to bulk-bill. We have a situation where we have an elderly population and a large number of people who are dependent on some sort of Centrelink assistance living in the area. The simple fact that they are unable to access a general practitioner who bulk-bills creates enormous hardship for them. When you add that to the fact that there are no local Medicare offices and people have to travel long distances, it is easy to see that the lack of a bulk-billing GP really does create problems for these people, especially those in the Central Coast section of the electorate where there is only a private transport provider. Therefore, I feel that the government really needs to act and to demonstrate a greater commitment to Medicare than just lipservice. The real commitment comes from ensuring that the pensioners in my electorate-and in every electorate, for that matter-can access bulk-billing. I find it very disturbing that we are seeing so much money being put into advertising which is directed towards the private health industry, while in my electorate I have a chronic shortage of doctors and many people who are missing out on being able to access bulk-billing. I would quickly like to move on to the issue of aged care. I am pleased to see that the minister is here. I want to hark back once again to the point I just made: the Shortland electorate is the 16th oldest electorate in the whole of the country. It is the 16th oldest electorate in the whole of Australia, and there is a problem with a shortage of beds in that area. I feel that beds need to be allocated fairly and evenly throughout the electorate. I would also like to express my concern about the fact that the beds that are being allocated within the area are being allocated more to private providers than to the community sector. I feel that the minister needs to take seriously some of the concerns that were raised with her when she met with providers in Gosford recently. They understand the area, and they understand the issues, and they were really disappointed that their concerns were not taken seriously. couple of things to say about the last speaker’s comments. First, I was very pleased to meet with providers in Gosford fairly recently and to get some very positive information for them. I do think they felt that their concerns were certainly being listened to. With regard to some of the points that were raised by the last speaker, I would like to make the point that in 1998 when the Auditor-General did a review of aged care he found that the previous Labor government had left a deficit of 10,000 places. He found that this was systemic, that it had occurred over a number of years and that, in order for the situation to be remedied, there was a need to inject an additional 10,100 places, in addition to providing for growth in numbers. I have followed the Auditor-General’s report, and in the time that I have been minister I have issued 32,000 places, counting the 9,500 places for the year 2001. With regard to beds, the Auditor-General also found that, in order for those to come on stream, it takes something between two and 2½ years for infrastructure to be made ready for the beds to go into but that it is necessary to release the beds so that the providers can then build the infrastructure knowing that their funding is guaranteed. The problem was that through the 1990s the Labor Party failed to release the beds, thus failing to get the process of building infrastructure to begin. We are having to deal with this as it was inherited. We can fix it prospectively but not retrospectively. Releasing those new beds means that the places are guaranteed, and they will bring them on as quickly as they can. With regard to the Central Coast, that area does need attention paid to it. The initial announcement was about how many beds were being released, and it showed that that was just over 9,500 for the year. With the allocation that will be advertised very shortly, the coming advertisements will show which areas are to be targeted. So that you understand the way in which the department recommends to me which areas should be the targeted areas, I will explain the process. Each state has a committee called an ACPAC, which is an aged care planning advisory committee. Each of those committees meets and considers the ABS figures, with five-year projections. Each committee considers the special needs groups, which are listed under the legislation. Each committee considers special issues and special pleadings that may come to them. Each committee then makes a recommendation to the department which then makes a recommendation to me. I would very much expect the Central Coast to be on that list, because the figures clearly show that it falls behind the ratio we strive for of having 100 places per population of 1,000 people aged 70 and above. That ratio was set by the Labor Party, but they never met it. Indeed, from 1986, they ran it down. This is bankable. After all, this money is paid monthly in advance; it is a constant and guaranteed stream of money which is very bankable, to use those terms. Many homes are taking this up and, in good management terms, are able to fund the infrastructure for the new beds and the recurrent stream that flows from that. I have been concerned that in parts of rural Australia there are some management problems, yet when I visit the home in Yeoval, which is run by the community, I see that the work they have achieved and the outcomes they get are just tremendous. It is a multipurpose service with acute beds as well as aged care beds, and the way it is managed by the community can be held up for a lot of other people to follow and copy. There is provision for conversion to community aged care packages. Allowing people to remain at home, where they really want to be, is a very strong part of the policy that I am pushing, developing and administering. The member for Calare said that there is often the same name on many lists for different homes, and this is perfectly true. I was told by somebody who actually is close to the industry that a family had met together and decided they would put their mother in a home, so they put the mother’s name down for 12 separate homes. The only problem was that, when the mother’s name came up, the mother said, ‘I’m not going into any home. I’m staying in my home.’ That became a statistic. The thing that has been very important to me in the last few months, and which I am promoting very hard, is the Commonwealth Carelink Centres. These centres provide information about the range of services we provide which enable people to remain at home. Up until now, this information was so hard to find. If you suddenly found that you needed services to help you bathe and dress in the morning, to help with the shopping and all those sorts of things that you need to remain independent, how would you find it? By ringing Commonwealth Carelink-1800 052 222-people can now find out where those services are. I hear from my 32 partners around the country who manage those Carelink Centres that the most plaintive plea is from people who ring and say, ‘They want to put me in a home. What services have you got that will keep me in my home?’ That is why community aged care packages are so well regarded and sought after. There were 4,000 of them when we came to government; we now have 24,000. With regard to the people who might want to look at that option, there is the provision to apply in the round when they are applying for whatever it is they might decide to do. Ms PLIBERSEK (Sydney) (7.06 p.m.)-I wanted to agree with the comments the member for Throsby has made in relation to detention centres. Unfortunately I do not have time tonight to go through the comments I had on detention centres, because there is another matter that I want to address. It relates to the treatment of people who are HIV positive who apply to come to Australia in the interdependency category. I am pleased that the minister is here, because I know that this issue has been raised with him by a number of my constituents. I want to refer to a letter that was written to me. Obviously I will not use the constituent’s name. He wrote to me on 27 February 1999: I met the man I will spend the rest of my life with. We are a defacto couple, very much in love and sure of our future together. My correspondent’s partner is a Canadian physician who is working in Sydney as a doctor. The man himself is also in the health care profession. Both of them are employed currently. Both of them have been contributing to the tax system. Both of them are keen volunteer workers. They are members of their local tennis club and go to yoga regularly. They are people who are contributing to the Australian economy and making a contribution as well to society. Let us call my correspondent’s partner ‘D’. He writes that D and he: completed all of the requirements set out so that he may become a permanent resident of Australia including a medical whereby he declared his HIV status. According to information that we have received from our case officer at DIMA, and an immigration lawyer working on our behalf, it is likely that our application forD’sPermanent Residency will be rejected on the basis of his HIV status. We have been advised that the current government considers that applicants with HIV pose an undue burden of cost on the Australian health care system. I want to point out that neither of us has ever been symptomatic of HIV illness, nor ever hospitalised because of this diagnosis. We are both on anti-retroviral medications that are working well to keep us both healthy. In factDhas an undetectable viral load and his T cell count has only improved since moving to Australia. The key point is that when DIMA make an assessment of how much someone who has the HIV virus is likely to cost the Australian community, they are working on figures that I presume were developed in the 1980s when HIV inevitably progressed reasonably quickly to full-blown AIDS. Of course that is not the fact at all these days, with the more sophisticated drug treatments on the market. The Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs assume a cost of about $239,000 over an unspecified but shortened lifespan for someone who has HIV. I have spoken to a number of specialists in this area, and their figure for drug treatments is $11,000 to $12,000 a year. The point I make is that both of these men are employed. They are in the work force. They are paying much more than $12,000 a year in tax, I am sure, and they are making a very important contribution to the community. There are also noneconomic factors that must be taken into consideration when we are making decisions about whether people’s interdependency visa applications should be agreed to. This couple own a home together. They have shown a great commitment to one another and are accepted by one another’s families as their life partners. This brings me to another matter when it comes to carers for people who become ill. speaker: Mr Price (Chifley) (7.15 P.m.)
theText: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for affording me theWednesday, 20 June 2001 MAIN COMMITTEE 28253 committee’s approval to release the eight hours of transcript of evidence from your departmental officials and ACMs that occurred after those visits. Ask me, because I wanted them published. I did not want to have in camera hearings. I wanted them on the public record. If you think the hard yards have not been done then let us release the transcripts. I am surprised that Alan Ferguson can be accused of being anything other than a loyal defender of your government. It is true that on three days we sat to discuss what we had seen, what we had heard and what were appropriate recommendations. Minister, I did not get every recommendation up that I wanted. I believe the biggest problem with detention centres is the lack of scrutiny. In our own state, Minister, we have an inspector-general of prisons who can do inquiries at the direction of a minister, who can do his own motion inquiries and who can hear complaints; and the Ombudsman’s role is not interfered with. You have that additional protection. We have an official visitors procedure. I would have liked to have seen an official visitors person for each detention centre. We did not follow that model, but we followed an independent one-one that you have so much disparaged. I believe that it is in all of our interests that we lift the lid on detention centres. Minister, you ask what message we are sending through the proposals that we offered. You are piloting a familythrough the chair. for families. We supported that. I wanted to go further, but the committee members said that you were taking action. I endorsed that, but you will note that the report said that the condition and treatment of families was a critical priority for the committee. We proposed that a target be set-and I can see that you have done a lot to reduce the processing time-of no longer than your current funded processing time. But we linked another recommendation to it that you have conveniently ignored: sponsorship, so that, yes, people can be released provided they are sponsored by an appropriate organisation. If they do not have a security clearance, if they are not sponsored, they are not let out of detention centres. Why has there been so much dissembling on this issue? Why won’t you give that a try, Minister? You ask what message softer treatment of people in detention centres sends back. What is the message, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the minister sends back by having 58,000 overstayers in this country? It is not bringing the country to its knees, Minister. In the year 2000, there were 2,800 people who arrived by boats and who were held in detention centres. What was it in the Netherlands? It was 50,000. In France it was 75,000. It was nearly 100,000 in the UK. Good luck to you. We have a minuscule problem compared to other countries. I congratulate you on that. But why can’t you and your departmental officials get it into perspective? Why do you deceive the Australian people so much? I only have 50 seconds left. This is a good report. It was honestly arrived at by men and women of goodwill from all political parties. It deserved consideration. I can understand when a report or its recommendations are not agreed to by governments. But what was most hurtful was the government’s attack on coalition members and the fact that the report did not receive careful consideration. theText: Minister, through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, you are proposing a pilot scheme28254 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 June 2001 fley said, the recommendations of the committee are very moderate compared with the need for action. Let us just mention one fact. Not only is the policy, and its implementation, quite wrong at the moment but we are spending more than $100 million in these detention centres. To achieve what? It is supposedly to send a message back to people that Australia is not a soft touch and that people will be treated in a certain way in relation to refugee status if they come in a boat-or if they are desperate enough to end up having to come in a boat. This is one of the biggest wastages of public money in social policy that we have had for a long, long time. The minister well knows that more than 90 per cent of the Afghans and more than 90 per cent of the Iraqis will be or have been accepted as genuine refugees. Notwithstanding this, we have had people in detention-and they have not merely been in detention. In talking to the people in Port Hedland and in Hakea Prison, I was stunned to hear that about 50 per cent of those who were allegedly accused of various incidents in relation to the 11 May event had been in the notorious isolation cell in Port Hedland prison-or Port Hedland Detention Centre. I used the word ‘prison’ but it is worse than a prison. The conditions in Hakea Prison are much better than the conditions in Port Hedland Detention Centre, there is no doubt about that. What did this isolation policy mean? It meant that people could be in this isolation centre for seven or eight months-and, in the case of one man, 16 months-before they had their first interview. I do not know who authorised this policy. I cannot believe that the minister authorised the policy that people would have to wait for seven months before they even had an interview-never mind how long they had to wait before there was a judgment about whether or not they were going to be given refugee status. That was before the first interview. We know from the parliamentary committee and from what we have been told by othersincluding what I was told-about the conditions of the especially notorious Juliet Block. I was not able to see Juliet Block and nor was the parliamentary committee. There is a very good reason for that: it is a total disgrace. It would in fact be condemnatory in international terms-not only the physical conditions but also other conditions, including not being able to contact their own wives and children for more than seven months. That is your policy, Minister. You may not be aware of all this. I think that you are not aware of this. I think you have been misled. You have been told lies. I am sorry to say that you have been told lies by officers and by people in the ACM who are trying to cover up. I was shocked at the atmosphere in Port Hedland; you could cut it with a knife. And the tensions and hostility between the two groups, the detainees on the one hand-and I am talking about all the detainees, not just the trouble makers-and the ACM people on the other hand, were really unbelievable to me. But has the minister really understood this? Is he really interested in resolving this? Is this the heritage that you want to go on with, Minister? If you look at what the Afghani community is saying at the moment about the extent to which Pakistanis are part of the caseload, I think we still have a major problem in relation to those matters. A lot of people have come who have relatives in Australia, and I suspect that many of them are looking for family reunion outcomes. They would find sponsors. If you are going to bring people who are looking for family reunion outcomes and link them with their sponsors and have them in the Australian community, if what they are looking for is migration outcomes, then they have achieved it. That is one of the concerns that I have about those sorts of suggestions. The honourable member for Calwell will resume hisThe following answers to questions were circulated: China: Bear Farming (Question No. 2535) Does the Australian Government have a position in respect of the Chinese Bear Farming Industry and in particular to bear bile and associated products; if so, (1) what is that position. (2) has he, or will he make any communication with the Chinese Government in respect to bear farming and the trade in bear bile and bear bile products. (1) The Australian Government views with concern the issue of cruelty of animals and concerns about reports of ill-treatment of bears in the Chinese Bear Farming industry, in particular reports concerning the ill-treatment of the endangered Asiatic black bear. Under the Commonwealth Wildlife Protection (Regulations of Exports and Imports) Act 1982, the import of Asiatic black bear products, including bile, is not permitted unless they are taken under a captive breeding program registered under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). There are currently no bear farming operations in China registered under CITES. (2) Australia has made representations to the Chinese authorities under CITES about traditional medicines containing prohibited products, including those of endangered bears, and will continue to do so. Separately, the Australian Government has strengthened legislation governing the trade in products derived from endangered species to make it easier to prosecute infringements of the legislation. It has also conducted a targeted public education campaign to promote awareness of wildlife conservation issues in order to reduce the demand for traditional medicines containing products of endangered species and to promote more appropriate farming practices. Foreign Affairs and Trade, Department: Representation in Ramallah (Question No. 2564) Mr Danby asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 22 May 2001: (1) What is the cost of the building of an Australian Representative Office in Ramallah, in the areas controlled by the Palestinian Authority. (2) When and who made the decision to build such an office. (3) What is the size of the Palestinian economy, in terms of GDP per annum, that this office will service. (4) What is the size of the Israeli economy in terms of GDP per annum. (5) How many Australian embassies or consulates have been opened or closed since 1996. (6) What was the size, in terms of GDP per annum, of the economies served by Australian diplomatic missions that have closed since 1996. (7) How does the Australian Government justify the cost of operation and construction, as well as future expansion of the Australian diplomatic presence in Ramallah, compared to the missions that have been closed. (1) The office is a leased floor of a seven storey commercial building in Ramallah. The lease commenced on 29 September 2001 for a period of 5 years. Rent is A$48,580 pa. The office fitout, including furniture and fittings, is scheduled for completion in October 2001 and has been budgeted at A$450,000. Posts Opened Abu Dhabi 1999 Copenhagen 2000 Dili 1999 (closed temporarily during 2000 unrest) Lisbon 2000 Los Angeles 1999 (upgraded from Austrade office) Ramallah 2000 Zagreb 1999 Posts Closed Almaty 1999 Copenhagen 1997 Damascus 1999 Nauru 1997 (6) The International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics, May 2001 and the Economist Intelligence Unit, report the GDP figures as: Copenhagen, Denmark USD$151.23 billion (1999) Damascus, The Syrian Arab Republic USD$16.2 billion (1999) Almaty, Kazakhstan USD$16.9 billion (1999) Nauru USD$50 million (1998) (7) Decisions on overseas representation reflect many interrelated considerations. They focus on maximising Australia’s economic and political standing to influence regional and global developments to advance Australia’s national interests, and take into account various strands of external policy, including foreign, trade, defence, immigration, and development co-operation considerations. Other factors may include the expansion of commercial contacts to help generate inward and outward investment, and the need for consular and passport services to Australians travelling and living overseas and to their families in Australia. Considerations of efficiency are relevant, both in terms of comparative costs in different locations and configurations, and in maximising our investment in the existing network.
